39606033.review:
Well folks we’re starting 2018 off strong with the Boyhood of gaming, that’s right, after 7 years Iconoclasts has been released and, as with Boyhood, it’s important to keep in mind that just because something’s been in development for a long time doesn’t necessarily mean it’s good. With that said, I have a confession to make here, and it really hurts me to have to say this because fans of mine will know that I always finish games before I write my reviews on them, but Iconoclasts, I don’t know if I can finish this game, I’m legitimately bored to tears here. I had a stream open where I was watching a guy play Fire Emblem and I thought that was more entertaining than playing this game. I’d be happy to go into more detail on that, just let me know in the comments, some really interesting tactics were put into action.

Do not for a second listen to anyone that describes Iconoclasts as a Metroidvania, because it’s more like Cave Story in the sense that it’s linear with chances for some very limited exploration, like that part where you have to collect all the dogs in the desert area (maybe it was cats). Now here’s where we run into one of our issues with Iconoclasts: there isn’t much there. Cave Story had health and missile upgrades that you could find as well as a variety of hidden items and weapons. In other words, if you went off the beaten path you would be rewarded. In Iconoclasts, the reward for every single optional challenge that I’ve found so far is one of four different types of ore. What do you do with the ore? I’m glad you asked, what happens is that you go to a workbench and trade in a certain combination of these ores and receive a “tweak” which you can equip into one of your “tweak slots”. Tweaks are minor upgrades, such as being able to stay underwater for longer or being able to take an extra hit. If you take damage, your right-most tweak slot will break; you start with three so if you take three consecutive hits your tweaks will be useless until you can collect special orbs by breaking statues (even healing at a save point doesn’t restore your tweaks). This is the only form of optional content in the game that I’ve encountered so far, is opening the chests and getting tweak materials that you won’t even end up spending because you have so many and none of the tweaks sound that interesting. What this means is that there’s very little motivation to do anything other than go exactly where the game tells you to go. Even if there were other types of optional rewards I’m not really sure what they could be, because, outside of boss fights, the game tends to focus more on platforming- and timing-based puzzles (which I’d like to add tend towards being tedious/boring more than anything else, now that I think about it I should probably focus on how boring doing the puzzles is but man the system with the tweaks really pisses me off) than combat; even on the hardest difficulty available when you start the game, enemies are fairly sparse and save points are so close together that health upgrades would be completely unnecessary. This is probably an identity issue more than anything else; Iconoclasts isn’t sure what it wants to be.

While the general pattern of gameplay is to run through however many puzzle rooms, maybe backtrack a bit in the process (very tedious), and then encounter a boss, Iconoclasts tries really hard to be a “narrative game”. There are, to put it nicely, way too many cutscenes and general gameplay interruptions in Iconoclasts. This might not be a problem if the writing was good or the story was interesting, but no, both are complete dogshit. The writing is incredibly cliched, and while the game tries to take itself seriously it just comes off as super ham-fisted because it’s impossible to see Iconoclasts as anything but a video game. The environments themselves are very video game-y, with levers and doors and locks and keys everywhere, there’s no attempt to try to make things fit into the context of the game world. The village that your character lives in, in classic JRPG fashion, appears to have a grand total of 5 or 6 residents. When you’re given directions, the characters don’t say “West” or “East”, they say “left” or “right”, like “go right of your house to reach the village”. I can’t believe that this setting exists, and as a result I can’t bring myself to care about anything that’s happening in it. The plot itself, I was going to try to describe it in a way that made it sound stupid, but it’s literally just about intolerance. It really isn’t subtle at all, there’s a big evil religion that controls everything and you know what who cares, it isn’t interesting, it isn’t believable, it’s communicated entirely through clichés, the plot of this game isn’t worth thinking about other than to wonder about why you have to waste so much time mashing through text boxes.

Iconoclasts looks nice but that’s it, it’s a one-trick pony, all style zero substance. Fighting the bosses isn’t bad but so much of the game is spent doing other, much more boring things. Also, the game is probably like 8-9 hours long. Hey, that’s reminding me of another game that I played recently, hmmm, that’s right, it’s No More Heroes 2: Desperate Struggle, developed by Grasshopper Manufacture for the Nintendo Wii and released in 2010! But wait, NMH2 is a good game, how could that be? Well, dear reader, that’s because NMH2 knows what it wants to be, you run at enemies, mash buttons, and eventually you fight a boss. Is the game filled with long cutscenes, is there even that much of a plot? Of course not, but even with how minimal the story is, you still get a sense of what the game is trying to do. NMH2 also had an entire team of devs working on it, so the risk of getting sidetracked from the primary goal was comparatively low. Iconoclasts, what is it, who is it for? It’s got Contra-esque bosses, but it also has a lot of platforming puzzles. It looks like it might be a Metroidvania, with the map and all, but it isn’t really? And it’s still trying to have a really heavy and impactful story despite the fact that implementing something like that clearly isn’t the dev’s forte? Ultimately, Iconoclasts is a lesson on why we need other people in our lives; they give us value, they give us meaning, and they prevent us from cluttering up our Cave Story fangames with puzzles and terrible writing.

Taster’s score: C-

39603066.review:
Welp, finished the game, and it was a hell of a ride.

Before I type everything, know I recommend this game whole-heartedly. It's a shining example of simple game design, executed amazingly well, created by a truly humble designer, Konjak. It's not perfect, but oddly that kind of coincides wonderfully with the overall theme of the game...

The gameplay itself is absolutely delicious. Motion is tight, responsive and goes at just the right speed to make traversal through the beautiful world rarely seem tedious. The stomp attacks and wrench grabbing have a little bit of homing on them, and generous hit boxes so as to allow the player to never really slow down. Think Metroid run speed with Megaman air control. Not only that you can increase this speed, making Iconoclasts a viable speed run game.

Combat is simple to execute, and bosses are fun and unique for the most part, save for one or two slightly frustrating set pieces. Konjak made a point to try and make all boss fights somewhat unique, and while in rare cases this makes some feel like a slog as you're trying to work out what to do, they all shine in one way or another. The other great thing is that it's clearly shown the moment they switch gears. Under their health bar is sometimes a selection of crystals, giving you an inkling of how many times this boss will switch tactics and a good idea of the time it will take. It's a simple yet very nice addition that I appreciate after loving Cuphead's progress meter after every death. It's also nice that the game does not subscribe to the 'hard game' trope that is often used to bloat an otherwise short game. It knows exactly what it wants to be without pandering to hardcore gamers.

Where this game really shines is its presentation. There are no voice actors present, and the game is dialogue heavy. However, the design, the beautiful animations, the actual thought put into how emotion is portrayed through text effects and the flow of it all really showcases the care Konjak had for the narrative. Each character is as flawed as eachother, [spoiler]including the main character Robin, who essentially by the end of the game is somewhat selfishly doing what she wants to do, rebelling against a world that tells her she can't do everything. Indeed her trying to do everything is sometimes the catayst for alot of misery, and even when saving the world, it was almost less about saving anything than to show her traumatised older brother that she doesn't need his protection, amking the whole end sequence almost a violent temper tantrum[/spoiler]. It really hammers home the weakness of humanity, how even the powerful are nothing more than human, and how we all find comfort in one thing or another, be it faith, family or even fear.

Still, as stated, it's not perfect. My main gripes have been miniscule at best, but still memorable as flaws. Some bosses are a tad obtuse, often several minutes spent trying to work out the path forward. Some people would probably work it out quicker than others, but there's an inconsistency to the help you get, like in some cases a partner in a boss fight will hint at you the way forward, but on other bosses they stay silent. While this is not too bad, being predisposed to getting hints can make some boss sequences a folly of trying to work out the correct bunch of powers or the right sequence. Once the gears start turning again however, they go down quickly and don't ever repeat the mistake. 

Another problem, again with the odd boss, is that there is A LOT going on. You can get lost in the mish mash characters as everyone explodes their flashy animations everywhere or dialogue attempts to distract you. It's rare, but it feels a little sloppy. When done correctly though, it's a visual feast.

My final gripe is that some heavily scripted moments can break, meaning that the game soft locks. I feel a quick restart function like in old Playstation RPGs would really help keep the pace going fast. Thankfully the game has some generous checkpoints and many save points so you never feel too overwhelmed. 

All in all, it's a fantastic narrative driven action platformer that delivers a near perfect experience. Fascinating, funny, equal parts heart warming and heart wrenching and polished to a mirror sheen, this game being worth the wait is a pretty huge understatement.

Get it, be inspired.

39596540.review:
I'm about 6 hours deep writing this, and I'll update my thoughts if I end up completing this game.

Iconoclasts isn't very good. While it may have the appearance of being well produced, it's hard to not feel that those efforts lie almost entirely in surface level aspects. Iconoclasts is a game that has somewhat satisfying movement, cool effects ,etc, and deserves notice for such, but this is about as far as my praise will go.

It's difficult to be concise about the problems Iconoclasts is plagued with as there is such a huge variance between them. Iconoclasts feels like a game that underwent many iterations, and instead of confidently embracing one, a messy cluster was settled upon instead. Part shooter, part puzzle, part platformer, part brooding drama, Iconoclasts fails to elegantly combine these aspects and instead presents a game where none of these aspects shine.

A majority of the gameplay in Iconoclasts is puzzles. While maybe not the focus of how this game is marketed, a primary chunk of time spent within the gameplay loop will be messing with switch puzzles of varying complexity. Every upgrade, 6 hours into the game at least, functions first and foremost as a new means of solving a switch puzzle. A problem with this, is that these puzzles don't combine new elements in a compelling or interesting way. Getting an electricity attachment for the grenade launcher doesn't mean that you solve problems in a new way, it just means that you have a new type of switch you can shoot. This alone isn't egregious, but to be frank it's pretty boring. Where Iconoclasts transcends from boring to annoying is the fusion of these elements with the combat and platforming sections. It is very often in Iconoclasts where a puzzle is made "more difficult" by having an enemy, or a bed of thorns placed to punish failure. These additions never make a puzzle more interesting, it frankly just makes them fucking annoying to deal with, especially given that the rewards for the optional puzzles are almost never worth it (see tweaks later). There is also a very frequent issue with the puzzles in this game where the primary source of difficulty is from elements being communicated poorly to the player. I haven't once yet had the ever sought after "A-ha!" moment from the puzzles in this game. Puzzles made me familiar with "well that was bullshit" more than anything else. On a related note, the mini map has outright lied about whether I can access rooms from above or below, making some of the exploration based puzzles terrible to experience (The Tower, notably. Rooms that need to be accessed from below saying they can be accessed from above, etc etc)

The pace at which you're given new gear & upgrades is disappointingly slow, especially given how little they actually change gameplay (as mentioned above). The lack of movement options makes platforming and exploration a total slog. It feels as if Iconoclasts is afraid to give players any movement options (I could be wrong given that I haven't completed the game) for fear of puzzles not being solved in the intended way.

Combat is a total bore, as most engagements are won by sitting and waiting to spam attacks, or using the exact same strategies over and over. Enemies aren't used in interesting and new contexts, they serve exclusively as annoying roadblocks to pad out game time.

Boss fights suffer the same communicative issues as puzzles mentioned earlier. I've had cases of bosses giving off explosions particles on hit, only to later learn that I wasn't damaging them at all. Boss fights are also very willing to throw in new mechanics at irelevant times, like spamming you with notifications that Mina has a shotgun when it isn't immediately relevant.

Tweaks as a system are baffling and annoying. They're not important enough to have any weight on your completion of the game, but they feel as if they exist to curb mechanical intrusions. The tweak to charge your electric wrench is a perfect example. Without the tweak on, a full wrench spin is about 1 tick too short of charging the wrench. It completes in one spin with the right tweak though. Getting the spin duration up tweak isn't a fun or meaningful change to my character. It feels like a feature that should've just been there already. Additionally, some of the most desirable tweaks are heavily gated for no discernable reason, such as "run speed up". It almost feels like the game doesn't want me to have fun at times.

Most egregious of these all is the writing. To be frank, the writing is pretty insufferable in this game. While the moment to moment banter is alright, the game will constantly derail itself as often as possible to exposition dump uninteresting lore and racial/cultural drama. I don't think I'm the only one so tired of seeing racial allegories being slapped on to titles so that we can pretend characters are more multi-faceted than they are. The racial and cultural tensions feel wildly insincere and half-assed. It's gotten to the point where I want to skip a cutscene if I see Mina talking. The writing feels more focused on angsty shouting and squabbling instead of any ideological confrontation. It feels almost patronizing how unspecific this drama is. If you do decide to play Iconoclasts, my sincere advice is to literally skip every dialogue scene as fast as possible. The drama presented in Iconoclasts is mostly a vehicle to push the plot. It is woefully non-concise, insincere, and worst of all boring.

Despite being what a lot of people probably believe to be considerably harsh, I look forward to seeing more projects from this developer. I'm not usually one for this phrase, but Iconoclasts is loaded with "potential". The bottom line is that in it's current iteration, it feels "undercooked".

39571373.review:
Awesome gameplay, beautiful art, catchy soundtrack, interesting story and lore, and even some genuinely funny writing.. this game has it all!

In a lot of ways, this game is a metroidvania.  2D exploration, insurmountable obstacles that will need to be revisited with the proper upgrades, etc.  It's also a little more 'driven' than some 'vania titles, as the story will often take you on a ride for a while to get you through important events, and then leave you free to explore your surroundings and advance at your own pace again for a while.

The reward to exploration?  Blueprints for new accessories, and the materials needed to craft them.  This game allows you to equip up to 3 'tweaks' at a time, but in order to get these, you'll need to find the blueprints and materials, which are often hidden in boxes in out-of-the-way areas, sometimes requiring some platforming or light/medium environmental puzzling to reach.  No grinding for materials by killing enemies, as all of them are found via exploration.  The more you explore, the more types of tweaks you'll be able to craft, and the less selective you'll have to be with which ones you decide to make.

The difficulty seems pretty mild during the 3 hours I've put in so far, but has been ramping up at a gradual rate to where I'm starting to feel challenged at times, so I think it's probably fine.  There is also a 'harder' mode availible from the start, which might be more ideal for those looking for a tougher game from the start. 

The lore and story of this game have been interesting to pay attention to so far.  The characters are also great, each with their own personalities, motivations, and backstory.  There has been some genuinely funny writing, too.. There are quips, sarcasm, blunders, and even a little bit of mild 4th-wall-breaking, which for me are always appropriate and never too over-the-top, and just enough to give the characters some extra pizazz, and a serious-but-not-too-serious vibe that I have been enjoying.

The graphics look great, of course.  You can tell that much from the screenshots and videos here on the store.  Unless you have a problem with sprites and pixel-art, you'll enjoy the quality of the drawing and animation.  Every inch of this game oozes life and atmosphere.  The music is catchy and pleasing to hear.  The sound effects are perfect, suiting the style of the game just fine and sounding great.  

In my opinion, this is the best game to come out so far in the month of January 2018.  Well-worth the money.  If you've been looking for something to play, and if this looks good to you, then I say go for it.  Quality through the roof, top-notch indie game.  I'm glad Joakim finished this game.  I admit I'd forgotten about it for a long time, but I'm so glad it resurfaced and is as great as it is.  

I wish I could think of at least one bad thing to write, but I just can't.  It's just so solid so far.. maybe I'll have some complaint to add by the time I finish it?

39566865.review:
The Rime of the Ancient Mariner is a poem written by Samuel Taylor Coleridge and published in the early 19th century about an old man who ruins a perfectly good wedding by telling a story about how he, as a sailor in his more youthful years, once shot an albatross who had been following his ship, a solitary act that would become his single defining aspect, his albatross to bear as it were -- a turn of phrase which owes its very existence to this long, hard-to-read poem.

Cave Story, created by Daisuke Amaya, or Pixel as he was known in the independent games community (or more accurately, the small, tribal pockets of the internet that would eventually collectively be called the independent games community as it gained attention from the mainstream gaming press in the coming years), was a 2004 platformer that instantly became the posterchild of the independent games movement. Its development alone, the hobby project of one man spanning a gestation period of half a decade, showed the world that one person, with a singular vision and a self-motivated drive to express themselves through the melding of both the sciences and the arts and a window roughly 640 pixels wide and 480 pixels high, could create a new, personal style of game that rivaled, and in many ways surpassed the experiences handed to us from the Nintendos and Segas of the heyday. This Metroidvania -- a portmanteau which owes its very existence to this masterwork of code, pixels, and FM synths -- would spark the powerkeg that would kick off the independent revolution.

It was amongst this backdrop that I, a starry eyed youngboy with a copy of Multimedia Fusion and a devil may care attitude would take aim to the skies and shoot down the albatross that would hang around my neck for decades. It was around this time that I began work on The Underside.

For a decade prior to this big mistake, I had been part of one of the lesser tribes of the proto-indie games community, the Click Community. Under the label "Fallen Angel Industries," I had worked alongside a few rabblerousers, one of which was a quiet swede who at the time was going by the name ZeroTau. His big project, his Moby Dick in this convoluted and barely cohesive string of nautical fiction references was a Monster World IV inspired platformer called "Mina of the Pirates," a swashbuckling adventure that starred the titular (or was it eponymous) heroine, Mina, who indeed was a pirate.

Years passed, the Click Community faded into obscurity, a few of its graduating members moving onto become indie games figureheads. Mina of the Pirates -- the game that had captured the hearts of the young boys and girls that had devoted their precious dial-up bits to arguing over bad South Park fangames and whether or not Derek Yu's Eternal Daughter was actually good or not (turns out it was, but I had not yet developed a discerning eye in my teenaged years) -- was nowhere to be seen. The name "ZeroTau" was scarcely seen without a dangling "Mina" modifier, and as weeks became months, and months became years, and the albatross grew heavier and heavier still. Perhaps it was the weight of the expectation coupled with Multimedia Fusion's finnicky toolset that finally did it, but Mina was canceled and as the game he had worked on for years faded in the public's consciousness, so too did the name ZeroTau. (I may of course be playing it fast and loose with the events of history for the sake of creating poetic flow.)

I know this feeling all too  well. I grew up creating games alongside ZeroTau, who now goes by the name Konjak. I too had that albatross project, for his Mina of the Pirates, I had my own The Underside. What began as a 16x16 box moving around the screen and shooting other 16x16 boxes with smaller, 8x8 boxes would eventually grow up to be the single game that defined my existence. Every new image I'd put out of the game would be passed around the dark corners of the internet like some weird pre-internet pornography. It's true, I once had the gall to end a 30 minute demo of the game with the words "coming soon" -- a phrase that would become a recurring punch in my career as a indie games developer.

Just as shooting that albatross would become the catalyst that would strand the ship of the ancient mariner at sea, The Underside, Mina of the Pirates, and yes, even Iconoclasts, the very game I set out to write about but have until this point failed to mention by name even once, all found themselves in development limbo, and their fans, the crew of the ship, once working together to steer the ship towards land found themselves veering off course and inadvertantly becoming agents of pressure and torment. In the poem, the other members of the crew end up succumbing to the sea left feeling nothing but emnity towards the mariner, shaping the mariner into the type of crazed old man who takes a perfectly happy wedding guest passerby and unpromptedly drops this sort of story on him.

Which is why it's an imperative that you play The Iconoclasts. This is to say nothing about how it looks or plays -- neither of these things should be a surprise to you if you've ever played Noitu Love or Legend of Princess, or if you have any sort of fond memories of the off-kilter, bouncy, kinetic feel of old Treasure games like Gunstar Legends or Mischief Makers. You can feel Konjak's poured his soul into every inch of the game, from the incredibly hand pixeled opening animation, to the little visual flourishes like the bouncy save confirmation prompt (yes, the save confirmation prompt in this game somehow manages to exude more charm than most games have in their best moments)

Instead, Iconoclasts is a game that exists in spite of its legacy -- you can, at times, feel a bit of Konjak in the story as Robin, a quiet mechanic with a very big tool quiety fights back against the One Concern, a legion of faceless fascists who publicly decry, but secretly kind of rely on Robin's skills as a mechanic. And not to beat a beat a dead horse with a big wrench, but to see Konjak finally release this thing, to kill Moby Dick and to take off that dumb bird necktie he's been lugging around for over a decade, well, it leaves THIS ol' grizzled mariner feeling a bit overstunned (a wonderful turn of phrase I hope I'll be seeing a lot more in the coming years)

Anyways, I hope you enjoyed my review of The Rime of the Ancient Mariner, it's certainly worth a read if you haven't already encountered it in your high school English classes.

39561453.review:
This game is so good I don't actually know how to put it into words.

Visually, it's on the same tier as Owlboy, which is saying a lot- pixel-art based games of this caliber are few and far between, and Iconoclasts is quite possibly the best there is. Every inch of this game is dripping with style, from the charming character sprites to the utterly gorgeous environment art- there isn't a section of the screen that isn't a joy to look at. The animation doesn't hold anything back either, and all that gorgeous pixel art looks great in motion.

The music is pretty good- and fits each area/boss really well. I haven't run into any songs that specifically stand out, but in general they've all set the tone really well.

The gameplay is pretty much what you'd expect from a quality metroidvania- you can jump, you can shoot, you can hit things with your giant wrench, and there's a whole bag of tricks to unlock throughout the game. Iconoclasts doesn't focus on combat as much as you'd expect, and apart from using enemies as mobile obstacles, for the most part running around in the world is more focused on puzzles & platforming challenges- at least early on. Which is actually kinda refreshing. Enemies also don't respawn often, so you aren't forced to re-fight everything while backtracking around puzzles.

Following that trend, the bosses are also more puzzle than fight in a lot of ways, and I spend more of my time trying to figure out how to exploit/reveal their weaknesses than plinking away at a massive healthbar. Each boss also completely unique so far, and have all been fascinating to fight.

You also get companion characters! Though they're plot limited so far, and generally only stick around for a bit, they're kinda fun to work with when taking down bosses- which is something I haven't really seen in this genre before.

Lastly, and almost most notably- this game's writing is really solid. Iconoclasts is set in an extremely broken world governed by a regressive, tyrannical religion that seems determined to keep everyone in the stone age. Almost immediately you're introduced to a handful of colorful (or not so colorful) characters, who paint a fairly vivid picture of the state of things. It's kind of crazy how stark of a contrast it is against the bright and cheery visuals, but it works really well. Despite that, there are still a large number of jokey moments that were absolutely hilarious, and caught me completely by surprise.

Overall, Iconoclasts is already one of the best games of 2018, and I doubt that opinion will change as I play through the rest of the game. If you're a fan of metroidvanias, you'd be remiss in passing on this one.

XBOX Oneコントローラーを使用。序盤をプレイした感想、クリア後に追記予定。

[u]崩れつつある世界で真実を追い求める為、跳ねっ返りメカニックな主人公「ロビン」と仲間達との冒険の旅が今始まる。メトロイドヴァニア系探索型アクションアドベンチャー。[/u]

[h1][b]【良い点】[/b][/h1]

◆ 美しいドット絵。今作では各キャラクターの動きのバターンが複数あり、どれも滑らかで自然な動きで表現されている。特に主人公の動きは可愛いものが多く、見ていて飽きない。

◆ 初期は銃での攻撃（チャージ可能）、レンチ（序盤で入手）を使用しての近接攻撃を駆使して戦闘をしていく事になるが、物語が進むと共に追加で武器が入手でき、これらの武器は謎解きにも使用する。

◆ ボス戦が多く、ストーリーの都合で仲間のキャラが戦闘に参加する戦いもあり、飽きさせない作りになっている。仲間のキャラクターが邪魔になるということもなく、かなり手伝ってくれる。

◆ 道中に入手できる素材を各所に配置されているクラフト台で使用することで特殊能力の付いたパーツを作成し、装備することが出来る。装備の能力は「一度だけ敵の攻撃を無効化する」、「主人公の移動速度アップ」、「レンチの攻撃力アップ」等だ。

◆ 上記した素材を集めてパーツをクラフトするのが面白く、ステージ中を回って素材を探してしまう。素材は無限に入手できるのではなく、マップの各所に配置されている宝箱などから一度だけ入手できる、所謂収集要素にもなっている。

◆ 今作でのマップは非常に見やすく、通過済みの場所にセーブポイントやクラフト台があったかはもちろん、宝箱があったかそれが取得済みかどうかまで表示されるので、探索がしやすい仕組みになっている。

◆ 難易度は「スタンダードモード」と「ハードモード」が用意されている。個人的にスタンダードは少し簡単に感じたので、腕に自信のある方は初期からハードでプレイしても問題ないかもしれない。

[h1][b]【悪い点】[/b][/h1]

◆ 物語の進行と共に別マップへ強制的に移動させられるのだが、序盤では以前のマップへと戻る手段がない。まあ、序盤で戻っても殆ど探索可能な範囲は広がっていないので、妥当だろう。

[h1][b]【総評】[/b][/h1]

まだまだ序盤だが、戦闘、探索、物語ともに高水準でまとまっており、現時点でも十分なボリュームがあることも窺える。ちょっとしたパズル要素も面白く、メトロイドヴァニア系が好きな方にはオススメだ。

プレイ動画をアップしているので、気になった方は[u][url=https://youtu.be/3VkcteuEFf8]こちら[/url][/u]を参考までにどうぞ。

[h1]Cómo ajustar las tuercas para crear una obra maestra[/h1]

En ocasiones al igual que sucede en otras artes, en el mundo de los videojuegos surgen personas que sin que nos los esperemos maravillan a todo el mundo con sus creaciones. Lo hemos podido ver con Eric Barone y su excelente Stardew Valley, y, desde ya, os aseguro que Joakim Sandberg es otro de estos pequeños grandes artistas, su obra Iconoclasts, así lo va a demostrar en las semanas y meses venideros. Puesto que tras 7 años de duro trabajo, se nota que aquí hay calidad y auténtica pasión por el mundo del videojuego.

Pero antes de nada, pongámonos en situación. Somos Alondra, una mecánica en un mundo gobernado por una sociedad religiosa en la que el uso de la maquinaria y el combustible que las hacen funcionar, el Marfíl, están estrictamente regulados por ellos, quienes dicen representar al dios al que todo el mundo teme, pues los pecados se pagan caros con la llamada Penitencia. Así pues, Alondra como mecánica debe medir cuidadosamente sus pasos si no quiere terminar en el punto de mira de esta organización que controla todo, o casi todo... Sin embargo, la aventura comienza con un acontecimiento que desencadenará una serie de sucesos que cambiarán la vida de Alondra y la de su planeta al completo para siempre. Y hasta aquí puedo decir, de verdad, a nivel argumental el juego me ha sorprendido muchísimo, es tal la profundidad que tiene en cuanto a lore que es algo que para nada uno se espera en este tipo de juegos.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1278882655

Vamos a conocer a muchísimos personajes muy interesante a lo largo de la aventura, tanto enemigos como aliados, cada uno de ellos con una personalidad y una épica arrolladoras, por momentos incluso vais a creer que estáis en un jrpg dada la cantidad y calidad de los diálogos. Es una trama que no solo se sigue con muchísimo interés, si no que además saber combinar con maestría momentos de humor, drama o acción. Y a la que solo se me ocurre una palabra para describirla; Sublime.

En cuanto a la jugabilidad, que es otro elemento importantísimo en esta clase de videojuegos, tranquilos, está a la altura de los mejores plataformas y/o metroidvanias que se os puedan venir a la cabeza. El control es perfecto, y las animaciones rápidas, los saltos los puedes ajustar al milimetro y tenemos una amplia gama de movimientos, desde saltar, agacharnos, reptar, engancharnos a los bordes... Nada se echa en falta cuando juegas a Iconoclast ni tampoco sientes que nada sea mejorable en ningún momento, de nuevo se vuelve a notar que su creador ha aprovechado mucho esos 7 años que le ha llevado crear esta maravilla virtual.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1278883916

El desarrollo del juego es una mezcla entre metroidvania y juego de plataformas, pues a principio avanzamos por zonas mientras dejamos otras atrás, no obstante llegados a cierto punto podremos regresar libremente a todas las ya visitadas, dando como resultado un enorme mapeado coherentemente interconectado. No en vano contaremos con el típico minimapa donde ver las habitaciones estructuradas en cuadraditos, por tanto, la exploración es fundamental para descubrir secretos. 

En los escenarios nos iremos encontrando enemigos a los que despacharemos con nuestra pistola aturdidora o bien a golpes cuerpo a cuerpo con nuestra fiel llave inglesa, que además ésta nos será útil para resolver ciertos "puzles" que encontraremos, los cuales siempre se combinarán siempre con plataformas, dando como resultado un gameplay que en ningún momento se torna monótono. Por supuesto conforme avancemos iremos obteniendo ciertos objetos que nos brindarán nuevas habilidades, al tiempo que nos permiten acceder a zonas previamente inaccesibles. Y además, podremos craftear ciertas mejoras que nos otorgarán más salud o mayor velocidad de movimiento etc. Por lo que esto último es otra capa más de profundidad en la jugabilidad.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1278883413

Por si fuera poco, el juego nos irá sorprendiendo a cada paso con pequeñas mecánicas que rompen por completo con la fórmula habitual de plataformeo etc. Por ejemplo, lo mismo estamos escapando de unos guardias con sigilo, que participando en un minijuego que simula el tres en ralla, por poner dos ejemplos. Y lo más increíble que es nada está metido con calzador, todo tiene su por qué a nivel argumental. 

Los jefes finales, que por cierto hay más de 20, merecen una mención a parte. El primero, muy simple, sí, solo es el tutorial... El resto, a cuál más original que el anterior, sinceramente, una sorpresa tras otra. Cada uno con sus mecánicas propias y bastante desafiantes (sin llegar a frustrar). No hay ni un solo enfrentamiento que mínimamente se parezca a otro, y eso en un juego con tantos jefes finales es todo un logro, os lo aseguro. Hablar de los enfrentamientos es hacer spoilers, porque de verdad, derrochan originalidad por los cuatro costados y están tan ligados a la propia trama del juego que es mejor no decir nada más. Tan solo recomendaros tirar por el modo difícil, ya que será una experiencia más satisfactoria, puesto que en este modo los jefes finales cuentan con más ataques y son mucho más divertidos.

Para terminar, el apartado gráfico y sonoro, decir que están a la altura del resto del programa. Cuenta con unas animaciones exquisitas, los personajes muestran muy bien sus emociones con ese pixel art tan bueno que tiene Iconoclast (mucho mejor in-game que en las imágenes, ya os lo digo) y la banda sonora es buenísima, con temas muy variados que mezclan sonidos retro con toques modernos muy bien medidos. Las canciones se nos quedarán grabadas en nuestra cabeza sin darnos cuenta. Lo que es una señal inequivoca de que tiene gran calidad. Y por cierto, el juego está perfectamente traducido al español,además de contar con una duración generosa de entre 12 y 15 horas.

39613189.review:
When roaming the show floor at PSX 2017 I happened upon an unassuming Iconoclasts booth and thought it looked cool, so I sat down to try it out. I played through a level, thanked the presenter, and walked away thinking that I was interested in the game, but that it seemed like it'd be too easy and have too basic of level design, but that it looked really nice.

Boy, I couldn't have been more wrong. Not only is the game  perfectly balanced and challenging in Harder mode, but the level design throughout the entire game is incredibly thoughtful and thought provoking. That's awesome alone, but there's actually also the most compelling story, world, and characters present in any 2D platformy-type game I've ever played. I think the biggest asset Iconoclasts has actually is not the gameplay (but the gameplay is awesome), but the cohesion of the entire world, the characters, its art style and its music. It all fits together so flawlessly that every time I played, I was entirely immersed in the world and the story, which is something I don't get from many games like this one any more. The characters in my party were my friends, and I felt every emotional blow done to them and every victory we achieved just as they did. The villains were expertly portrayed as well, as I had sympathy for them at the same time as wanting desperately to defeat them or escape from them. They also have some excellent character themes, which I'm a sucker for.

Iconoclasts is a masterclass of storytelling in the metroidvania genre (It's important to mention that Iconoclasts is more linear than you'd expect from a Metroidvania, so make sure you have that expectation), with an incredible attention paid to level design and gameplay as well as its beautiful art style and soundtrack. The only drawback I can think of is that I felt like it got a bit too wordy towards the end, but even still I think that's more of a personal thing than an actual (incredibly minor) issue. Buy this game. Play this game. I'll be coming back to it for 100% and even another play through because there's so much to see; What an adventure. There's no doubt in my mind that this'll be high on my list (if not #1) when it comes to game of the year.

Okay, before I explain why I do not recommand this game, I will make this one perfectly clear.
The game isn't terrible, but It's not great either.

There are some good moments in the game but there are many issues (Not game breaking issue, but rather something that detracts fun).

Structure- So the game is utilized the Metroidvania template. So you do have the map, and you do get to do some backtracking and everything. However, one of the great aspects about Metroid like structure is that you as a player wonders around the level and figure something out and then you learned something more about the game. "curiosity" is the keyword here. Because why explore when we already know what's in the environment? Now one problem with this game is that There is nothing to "explore". Yes, you do investigate the area to trigger the character dialogues to progress the main quest. But I don't really consider that as an "exploration". It just looks more of you moving to map to map until you find certain cinematic check point. Besides that you do have optional treasure chest to open, which you will be able to unlock "tweak" which is pretty much another word for "tool upgrades". These upgrades are pretty minor stuff that doesn't affect gameplay all that much. So in the end, you might as well just play the story part. not the other optional contents. Because those are not worth while contents. 

Story, Narrative, and Drama - Speaking of dialogues, Yes this game has a lot of dialogues. It's pretty much reminds me of Owl Boy. So from my understanding, the game is trying to be more of narrative based Metroidvania. Which I can understand that the game is about finding "trigger cutscene" around the map only if the game had actual interesting story or anything. But unfortunately, I don't find story was all that engaging. The writing in the game seems all over the place. While the character personality was pretty clear to me, but many character motivation or anything else seems confusing and flat out non sensical. So even the story here is not the strength of the game. It's rather weakness in the game. 

Music - Alright for the most part. None of them was all that memorable. So I have no strong opinion about that.

Combat and gameplay - This is probably the what game sorta best at it. But at the same time, it was pretty mixed bag for me. So majority of the game plays out like solve switch puzzle to find keys and figure out enemy weakness and counter attack them. Kinda like Zelda, Shantae, Owlboy. The thing is some of the bosses or some puzzles does expand little more than "Oh switch this and that" or "I have to use this gun hit boss's weakness to stun em". But majority of them are kinda like that. and after certain points in the game where the game is looks like to be an end game, the game starts to become more like walking to the certain linear levels to just fight bosses and this end game part has stretched out pacing. Which can be very exhausting... So even majority of the content here isn't all that well put together. It's just all over the place.

In other words, this game is just like Owlboy..
Pretty art, charming characters, and detailed animation. But the game itself is pretty shallow. and really, you are not exploring the area. You are just finding the cinematic cutscene.

If you want to play decent Metroidvania, you can't go wrong with this game.
Because as a game, It's not really broken game that you can't enjoy.
The game in general is okay to play.

But If I have to recommand other Metroidvania game...
You can either try Ori & Blind Forest or Hollow Knight
These two are usually my best Metroidvania up to date IMO.

40909845.review:
[h1][b]Review | Iconoclasts[/b][/h1]

Iconoclasts, desenvolvido pela Konjak, foi um jogo com um desenvolvimento conturbado, pois em alguns momentos o desenvolvedor não se sentia motivado com o seu projeto e estava quase desistindo de concluir o jogo, fazendo com que o público que acompanhava pensasse que o jogo estava abandonado, porém depois de muito tempo sem noticias do jogo, em 2014, veio o lançamento de uma demonstração alpha disponível para o público jogar. O jogo foi muito bem recebido pelo público que esperava ansiosamente e com isso ele voltou com tudo no desenvolvimento, concluindo o jogo no dia 23 de janeiro de 2018.

No jogo você é Robin, uma garota cujo o pai era um mecânico de um mundo repleto de máquinas onde só os mecânicos eram capazes operar. Robin queria seguir a mesma profissão do pai, porem uma das religiões decide proibir esse oficio, mas Robin desobedece essa religião e continua a utilizar a chave inglesa, herdada do seu pai, pra ajudar seus amigos. O jogo possui uma história bem complexa, que s eu falar mais um pouco além disso, vou acabar soltando spoilers, o que posso dizer é que após acabar o jogo você vai refletir um pouco mais sobre as coisas que acontecem no nosso mundo e passar a se questionar sobre elas.

Desenvolvido por uma unica pessoa, esse metroidvania, não é um exemplo que todos devem seguir, com grandes inovações e tudo mais que todos esperam que tenham após dez longos anos de desenvolvimento, mas não é porque não tem grandes inovações, que não existe qualidade, já que em toda a sua gameplay o jogo traz uma gama de sentimentos e realizações após cada desafio vencido, fazendo com que a empolgação de ter que continuar jogando continue mais e mais.

[h1][b]GAMEPLAY[/b][/h1]

O gameplay é bem satisfatório, apesar de ser linear, ele é bem fluido, algo que eu foco bastante em minhas jogatinas, já que é isso que vai definir se eu continuo a jogar ou não. Apesar de ele ser bem linear, ele ainda tem partes de exploração, fazendo com que você volte algumas vezes para mapas que já tenha passado, mesmo que por poucas vezes e o que me deixou desanimado foi o sistema de upgrades, que é bem simples e não agrega em muitas coisas, fazendo com que eu chegasse ao fim do jogo sem ter que usar nenhum deles, mostrando o quão inúteis eles são, mas alem desses upgrades, existem outras armas, que no decorrer do jogo você vai encontrar para derrotar bosses ou para usar na resolução de puzzles. Os puzzles desse jogo também foi algo que me deixou bem decepcionado, já que a resolução deles é bem simplória e as vezes eu passava por um sem perceber. Os bosses, apesar de serem memoráveis e bem trabalhados, não eram tão difíceis, pois como em todo metroidvania é só decorar os padrões e fim, porém não joguei a versão do NG+, então posso estar enganado enquanto a dificuldade do jogo.

[h1][b]AUDIOVISUAL[/b][/h1]

Quanto a arte do jogo, ela é simplesmente espetacular, é difícil até de imaginar que foi somente uma unica pessoa que fez o jogo inteiro, pois o jogo possui uma ótima fluidez nos movimentos e animações muito bem feitas. O jogo também possui algumas cutscenes, que são feitas completamente em pixels e tenho que dizer, são maravilhosas. O level design do jogo também é bem impressionante, pois a interação do personagem com o cenário é bem completa, fazendo com que quase todo o mapa possa ser explorado. E a trilha sonora não desaponta, mas não é nada de espetacular, só é algo que da pra jogar escutando, porém se considerarmos que o jogo inteiro foi feito por um, podemos dizer que estamos na presença de um gênio.

O que podemos concluir é que Iconoclasts é um ótimo jogo, que contém um ótimo gameplay, arte e trilha sonora, mas o que mais chama atenção é a história profunda que o jogo apresenta, uma pena não ter o idioma pt-br, mas eu andei pesquisando e descobri em um vídeo do youtuber "Sr. Wilson", do canal Colonia Contra Ataca, que em uma conversa que ele teve com o desenvolvedor, ele disse  planejava traduzir, não é uma informação oficial, mas pelo tempo e quantidade de inscritos, o canal deve ter uma credibilidade alta.

[b]Prós:[/b]
Ótimo gameplay;
Arte belíssima;
Boa trilha sonora.

[b]Contras:[/b]
Chefes consideravelmente fáceis;
Não possui tradução pt-bt (até agora);
Puzzles bem fáceis.

[h1]The game I've been waiting for... for a very long time.[/h1]

I [i]need[/i] to write a review for this game.
I [i]needed[/i] to write a review for this game.


[b]Graphics: 10/10[/b]

Nothing beats the old-school pixel art. It's not even a matter of "Oh, it's a 2D Sidescroller and there are tons of those around," it's the fact that the developer took time to add detail to everything, [spoiler]Robin even has a booty.[/spoiler] Each map, each character sprite, each effect - they paid enough attention to detail to deliver a colorful world, even when the atmosphere was gloomy or creepy. You can't beat graphics like this, especially in this element.

[b]Music: 9/10[/b]

I play the game mostly on mute, so I can't really give this one a score. From what I have heard, I enjoyed it a lot. But it won't be fair for me to say 10/10 when I haven't heard half of the soundtrack.

EDIT: I've almost completed the game now. And I love the feeling you get after hearing the track [spoiler]when you fight Black and what I think is also Black by the rocket ship[/spoiler].

Only reason this is getting a 9/10 instead of a 10/10 was because it's not very easy to put emotion and atmosphere into pixelated game soundtracks. But Konjak managed to do it somehow, especially during certain fights.

[b]Gameplay: 100/100[/b]

I've read other reviews where people liked Iconoclasts at first but started to dislike it as they played it more. Maybe it's because [spoiler]you get characters in your party that aren't playable unless you're in certain conditions/situations, making the whole "party" system kind of useless for most of the game. But if you understand that the main character is actually Robin and her "mechanic" status is the centerfold of her adventure, then it wouldn't really be a problem.[/spoiler]

I'm a huge Mega Man X fan, so the [spoiler]stun gun[/spoiler] right off the bat had me leading towards a positive review; and if you're a metroidvania fan, you'll also appreciate it.

The "you'll have to come back here later in the game" element in games is always a huge plus to me; it makes the game non-linear, as opposed to being given the tools in that particular area to get past that said particular area. Iconoclasts does a great job of showing you that there's something in an area that you may have stumbled on ([spoiler]which may or may not be at the beginning ;)[/spoiler]), but you will indefinitely have to come back to it later because you probably don't have a certain tool or weapon that's required to interact with [i]anything[/i] around there. There's even a map that's EXTREMELY SIMILAR to the map in Super Metroid that shows you where you are, where you've been, and a legend to help you determine what's what.

The boss fights are fun, interactive, and not repetitive; each boss is different from the last and some of them actually make you think; and if you take too long to think there's someone/something that gives you a [i]hint[/i], not the solution, a hint on how to beat the boss.

I tried to get myself stuck a couple of times, but they did a really good job with the density of the objects, so that's a plus too.

[b]Characters: 8/10[/b]

I like the dialogue between the characters. I like how each one interacts with the other. They're not drone NPCs, most of them have character to them, [spoiler]except that one guy in the church who serves as a "Information" NPC for the whole game.[/spoiler] Some of them will make you laugh and giggle, while others will make you feel for them. Some NPCs you may even hate. Call this something common in games, but it really isn't easy to personify almost [i]every[/i] NPC in a game when you're worrying about the main cast.
[spoiler]Black's story is sad. Very, very sad.[/spoiler]

[b]Story: TBD/10[/b]

I haven't completed the game yet. I'm trying to find every detail and area to go in to obtain every item possible. So I'll get back to this (hopefully).

40886792.review:
Iconoclast starts off as a beautifully-animated Metroidvania-style adventure game, and as you unlock new abilities the fluid animation, hectic action, and tight controls put it among the best I can think of in recent history. But what unfolds in the meantime is something pretty special.

Iconoclasts, as the name (somehow deceptively) intimates is a game about religious faith and humanity buried under its bright sprites and bouncy music. It's hopeful at its core, but this game gets brutally dark in its attempts at exploring the questions it brings up, and it never shies away from any ugly revelations.

Some thinly sketched characters are given increasingly deep motivations, trauma is revealed, conflicts arise and complicate relationships, and though you can't change the direction of the game, you do have the ability to slightly direct conversations with multiple-choice dialogue.

It's a little over 12 hours of game time if you avoid the fluff and exploration (hidden chests only provide materials for crafting "tweaks" -- equippable bonuses -- but since you can craft most tweaks pretty early, it's mostly score-keeping), but it never gets boring and never slows down. I'm absolutely enthusiastic about this game.

10/10. Absolutely.

40701060.review:
-::FAMILY SHARE REVIEW WARNING::-

A delightful metroidvania romp, with a far stronger focus on story than most games in the genre, and simple yet tightly crafted gameplay that keeps you engaged the entire game.

While it pulls incredibly strongly from metroidvania design conventions, it's far more linear than other similar games. Personally, I view this as a benefit, as it drastically reduces the amount of backtracking you'll be performing bar for a few short segments, though even then said segments effectively serve as breaks between each of the story's "acts", and ultimately will be unlikely to negatively influence your enjoyment.

Areas -are- almost always re-visitable, though this only really serves to allow you to grab a few extra upgrade materials using gear you picked up in later areas, and it's refreshing to play a metroidvania that leaves the constant re-running through old areas as an optional side gig rather than a requirement.

The gameplay itself is simple, but uses its simplicity to great advantage. Your abilities at first are just jumping, shooting a basic projectile, and swinging/grabbing with your wrench. Over the course of the game you'll only get three more abilities (a bomb shot, teleport shot, and the ability to electrify your wrench to ride power lines/power up objects), but in using interesting combinations of these abilities both the puzzles and combat stay fresh and keep presenting you with new and unique challenges, so you never feel like you're rehashing old puzzles/encounters.

Also, the difficulty balance is spot-on. I never got stuck enough on a puzzle to necessitate checking a walkthrough, but still had to actually use my brain to reach the solutions. Some of them even have trick shots/jumps you can make to reach the solution in an unconventional way, which is always a treat.
Combat against regular enemies isn't incredibly challenging, but doesn't feel like a chore either, acting as quick reflex tests to keep you on your toes between bosses. This in mind, bosses -are- challenging, but never feel unfair. It's not unexpected to die once or twice on a boss, but in turn you can reasonably clear each your first attempt if you're careful and observant enough of their patterns.

Moving on, the story is very well presented and takes plenty of interesting twists and turns. Even if you don't find the gameplay gripping, you'll likely want to keep going anyway to find out what happens next. 

It feels like the developer made sure to fully flesh out the entire story of the world, and then explain only the parts relevant to the main plot as they're brought up, which works great as it makes everything feel like it has an internal consistency to it. While some people might be irked by not having every aspect of the lore revealed to them, I deeply enjoyed it as it made me feel like I was actually someone exploring the world and learning about it, rather than having all the information handed to me in a big pile of exposition or codex lore entries as some other story-heavy games do.

Characters are just as fleshed out as the world, letting you get invested in their individual plights and genuinely sympathize with both the protagonists -and- antagonists. They actually interact with each other with that level of unpredictability real people have, avoiding tropey and easily-predicted dialogue chains that many games nowadays are plagued with. In turn, dialogue (mostly) flows naturally and can feel like the characters are having actual conversations instead of just exchanging lines back-and-forth.

On the note of the "mostly", a few conversations did have a bit of awkwardness to them, as if the developer was trying to decide between one of two lines for a scene, but liked both too much and so tried to shoehorn them both in, though this is never particularly egregious, and is generally relegated to the less-serious plot moments.

Also, the spritework is pretty great, which acts as a big help to the story, as characters have a ton of unique sprites/animations that they use during cutscenes that really lets the story show with a level of detail you'd normally only be expecting out of a 3D game.

In turn, the soundtrack was p dope, especially the unique tracks used for the last few bosses/areas that really help amp up the emotion of the encounters.

In closing, you can tell the developer poured his heart and soul into every aspect of this game, and while nothing is ever perfect, he comes damn near close. Fans of character-driven stories and metroidvanian platformers alike should get a heapfull of enjoyment from it.

9.2/10

40540955.review:
[h1]Iconoclast[/h1]

[b]Einleitung[/b]

Iconoclast ist ein Metroidvania mit guter Story, Humor und lustigen, aber auch emotionalen Dialogen. Für Alle die nichts mit dem Begriff Metroidvania anfangen können hier eine kurze Einführung:

Metroidvania ist ein zusammengesetztes Wort aus "Metroid" und "Castlevania". Beim dem Begriff ist das Design des Spiel gemeint, d. h. in der Welt gibt es Regionen oder Gebiete die erst mit einer Fähigkeit oder einem Skill erschlossen werden können, welche man im Verlauf des Spiels findet. Der Reiz bei Metroidvanias ist, dass man immer neue Skills/Waffen/Fertigkeiten bekommt, die das Spiel abwechslungsreicher und interessanter gestalten. Die Ur-Vertreter sind, wie eingangs schon gesagt, Metroid und Castlevania, aber es gibt noch andere, neue Vertreter des Genres, wie zum Beispiel "[url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/chaoslicht/recommended/332200/]Axiom Verge[/url]", "[url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/chaoslicht/recommended/367520/]Hollow Knight[/url]" oder  "[url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/chaoslicht/recommended/283640/]Salt and Sanctuary[/url]".

Aber wieder zurück zu Iconoclast. Die Story des Spiels ist meiner Meinung nach sehr gut gelungen und kommt auch durch die Dialoge sehr gut rüber. Eine Sprachausgabe fehlt komplett, aber das stört nicht im Geringsten. Die Charaktere passen sich gut ins Spiel ein und deren Handlungen sind immer nachvollziehbar bis auf eine, die fast am Ende der Story auftaucht. Was die Entwickler sich dabei gedacht haben, ist mir vollkommen schleierhaft.... Trotzdem ist auch das Ende der Geschichte durchdacht und rundet das ca. 10 Stunden lange Abenteuer gut ab. Wer alle Kisten finden will kann ruhig nochmal 3-4 Stunden mehr einplanen und der NewGamePlus- und Herausforderungsmodus laden dann noch zum neuen Durchgang ein.


[b]Ich habe einen Schraubenschlüssel![/b]

Wie es sich für ein Metroidvania gehört, springen, laufen und erkunden wir die Welt in 2D. Ja, es gibt auch 3D-Metroidvania, aber nur 2D ist das Original! Jedenfalls sind wir auf einem wunderschönen Planeten und spielen die blonde Mechanikerin Robin. Die etwas schüchterne und sprachlose (wenn auch niedliche) Mechanikerin reist im Verlauf des Spiels an schöne, kalte, karge und beeindruckende Orte, an denen es immer etwas zu bestaunen und zu endecken gibt (Stichwort Kisten). Das Spiel verfügt über ein sehr kleines, rundimentäres Crafingsystem, wobei "System" sehr übertrieben ist. Man sammelt nur 4 Elemente, die sich dann zu einem Boost zusammensetzen lassen. Notwendig ist das eigentlich nicht, aber schon sinnvoll, da man z.B. länger unterwasser bleiben kann oder mehr Treffer einsteckt. Der oben erwähnte Schraubenschlüssel dient als Waffe (Nahkampf) und für Rätsel.


[b]Schraube locker?[/b]

In der Welt sind kleine Muttern verteilt die wir mit dem Schraubenzieher... naja festschrauben können, dass wiederrum ist nötig um Türen oder kleine Schalter- bzw. Schraubenrätsel zu lösen (wobei lösen... man schraubt die ja fest....). In den Bosskämpfen spielt der Schlüssel ebenfalls eine feste (hehehe...) Rolle, mal müssen wir ein Tür öffnen damit wir entkommen oder wir schicken Projektile wieder an den Absender zurück, spart Portokosten. Aber allein mit dem Schraubenschlüssel kommen wir nicht weit und so haben wir noch eine kleine Pistole, die über einen normalen und über einen aufladbaren Schuss verfügt, in der Tasche. Im Spielverlauf gibts ein paar Upgrades für Schlüssel und Pistole, diese sind zwar überschaubar, aber würzen das Spiel auch mit Abwechslung. Leider gibt es bei den Upgrades keine großen Überraschungen, da helfen auch die Craftinggegenstände nicht weiter. Macht aber nix. Das Spiel überzeugt mit seiner Einfachheit und der guten Spielbarkeit, eine Vielzahl an Waffen oder Upgrades würde hier nur das Gameplay stören.


[b]Da geht doch noch mehr, oder?[/b]

Im Prinzip ist es das auch schon. Die Story schickt uns über die gesamte Karte und bringt einige emotionale Momente mit sich, die auch danach noch im Gedächtnis bleiben. Außerdem kommt es vor, dass man dem NPC, mit dem am gerade redet, antworten muss. Ob das irgendwelche Auswirkungen hat? Nun, dass kann ich ehrlich gesagt nicht sagen, aber in den Diskussionen bei Steam sieht es so aus als könne man damit das Ende beeinflussen. Nach dem Ende ist es allerdings nicht möglich weiterzuspielen, es sei denn man lädt des letzten Spielstand oder man fängt gleich mit eine NewGamePlus an.


[b]Und nun ein Fazit![/b]

Iconoclast ist ein gutes Spiel, ein Metroidvania, was sich auch als solches bezeichen darf. Die Grafik fängt die Atmosphäre stets gut ein und auch der Soundtrack ist immer sehr schön. Auch die Story war niemals langweilig, da es viele lustige, aber auch ernste Momente gibt, die nicht übertrieben oder kitschig gezeichnet wurden. Mit ca. 10 Stunden Spielzeit ist, bei 52% eingesammelter Komponenten, ist das Spiel definitiv eine Empfehlung wert und falls Ihr lust auf ein kleines Abenteuer habt, Robin ist bereit mit euch die Welt zu retten. Ganz bestimmt!

[b]Geschrieben am 03.03.2018[/b]

40496837.review:
[h1] ICONOCLASTS REVIES - Heartfelt adventure worth your every penny! !!SPOILERS!! [/h1] 

It has been long overdue but totally worth the wait - Iconoclasts is here to knock your heart out with lovely characters, interesting ideas, engaging gameplay and more! Iconoclasts is 2D metroidvania with puzzling, unique setting and amazing visual looks. You play as Robin a mechanic's daughter (silent, yet expressive protag) who lives in a sad and cruel world built on faith and co-operation with organization named One Cornern. World is basically dying and you're set to unveil what dark secrets One Concern and the current death of this planet holds! 

[h1] GAMEPLAY - 8/10 [/h1]

Iconoclasts gameplay revolves around metroidvania styled gameplay. You can move to left and right, jump up and fall through certain platforms if you choose to. You have a progression system as usually follows - you go through the story and get new powers leading you to new powers while letting you run free around the rather big 2D styled world to backtrack and collect secrets. What's so unique about Iconoclasts then? Well, like I pointed out earlier, the game is rather built around puzzling, your solve puzzles with your meelee weapon, the Wrench which gets more upgrades along the way to spice things up. You can turn bolts to open doors and interract with almost all of the puzzles in the game. First of all, Robin controls smoothly and jumping never feels off except one certain parts which I'll return to later. You can also whack enemies with your Wrench and parry certain projectiles by performing a meelee attack in the right time window. Alongside your meelee weapon, you also get 3 different gun types with regular fire type and charge shot. 

STUN GUN: Medium Damage with charge shot to break through walls and damage enemies in the expense of being vulnerable until it charges back (happens with all of the gun types).

BOMB GUN THING: Heavy Damage with bombs and charged rocket to solve puzzles. These bombs help you to move certain obstacles and damage enemies. 

WEIRD SWIRLY TELEPORTATION GUN: Major Damage, shoots swirly particle thingy that passes through enemies making piss easy later in the game. Charging this gun will perform teleportation that swaps your place with enemies or certain objects depending who you shoot it at. 

Iconoclasts also comes with a stomp move which I loved. It was there from the start and it feels heavy and impactful. Stomp can be used to damage enemies or break breakable blocks underneath you. 
You will also get a charged electric power which lets you break through said blocks while traversing through electric wires. This is an interesting mechanic which gives a bit more variation to the puzzles. Why isn't the gameplay 10/10? Well  there few issues, enemy placements fall on the bad side time to time, enemies can be spammy or just downright insanely irritating, sometimes you will take damage because the enemies react way too fast. Secondly the puzzles get rather stale sometimes, they good for the most part but they get rather stale by the midway (they do get better tho!). I also find the perk system sometimes way too forgiving and sometimes way too punishing - you have perks which you can craft by collecting certain materials found across the map. You take damage = the perk gets destroyed until you fix it by collecting cubes from enemies, puzzles, opening doors or bosses. Why does this feel inconsistent then? Some enemies drop way too many cubes, you can stack them rendering some bosses and puzzles ridiculously easy and it just didn't sit well with me. Some bosses can also be oddly spammy at times, giving you no space to move making you unable to go through without taking damage, this can lead to some irritating situations but these are few and far between so I wouldn't complain about it too much. Solid gameplay that gets hindered by few issues listed above but it fits the world.

[h1] CHARACTERS AND STORY - 9.5/10 [/h1]

The characters and story were mostly what kept me coming back when the puzzles were feeling stale. I was engaged, I was riveted by what was gonna happen next. Iconoclasts holds nothing back, the story is sad, cruesome and philosophical. It's led by a narrative that pokes and gives criticism to extreme religiousness, human experiments and over usage or fuel. Every piece or dialogue is interesting and you'll form each of them their unique voices in your head because they are so quirky and fun to talk to! You'll see many colourful characters along your journey but I'll mention the most notable ones: Royal, Agent Black, Mina and Elro. These characters are amazing and all of them alongside the story need to be experienced on your own. It's that good and my rambling wouldn't do it justice. Good stuff!

[h1] GRAPHICS - 10/10 // MUSIC - 8/10 [/h1]

Graphics in this game are fantastic. It's pure eyecandy and it shows how much effort has gone into this department. Every character is expressive, colours are vibrant, cutscenes are beautifully animated and the game is just...it just looks so good. It's unbelievably made and fluidly animated. The music is good but that's as good as it gets. It fitst the theme and looks but it's mostly good and nothing mindblowing. Sound design however is on point. 

[h1] LEVEL DESIGN - 8.5/10 [/h1]

Level design in Iconoclasts can be described with one word - stellar. The level design plays well with it's puzzling elements and nothing feels too exploitable regarding the level design. It's decent with enjoyable platforming and unique worlds. You have your basic first worlds like grass themed one, desert and snow level but these worlds get elevated by the quirky world design and graphics. It didn't too generic but it would've been nice to see these three not be included. Other than that the level design is very enjoyable with multiple settings and sometimes dreary athmosphere when it gets to it. Very solid stuff!

[h1] CONCLUSION - OVERAL SCORE 9/10 [/h1]

Iconoclasts is a fantastic experience with unforgetable characters, amazing visual design and riveting story. It gets hindered by few issues but the positives outweigh the negatives and crush them under stellar design. Iconoclasts is fantastic and if you have 20 euros to spend and roundabout 15 hours to use, it's a no brainer.

Un personaje principal que quiere ayudar a los demás es el principio de Iconoclasts, un juego que se basa enteramente en esta idea principal. "¿Puede una mecánica arreglar el mundo?" Eso reza la publicidad del juego y lo que intenta mostrarnos durante la aventura.

Manejamos a Robin (Alondra) una mecánica que armada con una llave y una pistola recorrerá diversos lugares en un mundo que combina un ambiente apocalíptico con ideas religiosas; el estilo de juego es uno tipo metroidvenia, es decir, tendremos que ir de un lado a otro resolviendo puzzles y mejorando nuestras herramientas para seguir avanzando. Contrario a lo que puede parecer en un primer momento: el juego es bastante lineal, prácticamente el juego se basa enteramente en lo siguiente: una puerta cerrada en el lugar A que solo se abre con una llave que está en el lugar B, por lo que hay que ir por ella y mientras hacemos esto, combatimos con enemigos típicos de juegos como este. Todo el juego, hablando de sus mecánicas, es de hecho bastante simple y lo que necesitamos para completarlo se nos da muy temprano, dicha simpleza es un arma de doble filo ya que si bien, agradezco que no sea saturado con muchas cosas, si me hubiese gustado que se le de más variedad a la jugabilidad ya que el juego dura más de lo que uno espera: me tarde poco más de 15 horas, y creo que el rango esta entre 10-16 horas (en tu primera partida) dependiendo habilidad y ganas de explorar el mundo. Tanto tiempo haciendo lo mismo llega a ser un poco cansado y por eso un poco más de profundidad jugable no hubiese estado mal. 

Por ejemplo: en una parte del juego nos dicen que necesitaremos del sigilo para poder triunfar; sin embargo eso no es cierto, ya que vas a ir disparando como loco y no afecta en nada a la aventura, me hubiese gustado que lo hiciera. No estoy pidiendo nada complicado, por ejemplo hay una parte muy ingeniosa en donde debemos ayudar a poner cajas en su lugar pero si hacemos una combinación equivocada, estas explotan. Hubiese agradecido más momentos así, sobretodo porque como dije, el juego es más largo de lo que aparenta. Aunque eso si debo decir: las batallas contra jefes son todas espléndidas, muy divertidas, que aprovechan las mejoras de nuestro equipo y en general un desafío interesante. Dos de esas batallas se han convertido en algunas de mis batallas favoritas de todos los tiempos, si acaso solo por lo que significan dentro del juego.

Pero bueno toda esa simpleza en lo jugable es debido a que el juego es guiado por la historia, la cual, como mencioné al principio, tiene elementos apocalípticos y religiosos. La idea de un mundo donde los recursos se están agotando y hay muchos temblores mientras tienes a una sociedad que castiga a los "pecadores" y le rezan a un ser superior está bien llevada y todo gracias a personajes muy interesantes. Tienes a un personaje que siempre se molesta cuando las cosas no salen como quieren, a uno que quiere ayudarte pero siempre que lo hace termina empeorándolo todo y tu hermano que es apático a todo lo que acontece durante el juego y que en su afán de cuidarte termina cada vez más lastimado. Los personajes sienten, actúan y sufren por los acontecimientos que ocurren antes y durante del juego. Todos me gustaron a su manera y agradezco que hayan tenido tiempo en mostrar sus personalidades. En general me gustó muchísimo la historia y los personajes que esta tiene pero tristemente tengo que decir que tengo un problema con el final, el cual no revelaré por obvios spoilers, pero si diré que por todo lo que se estaba formando uno esperaría un final trágico o al menos agridulce, y no es el caso. Es decepcionante que el juego, después de todos los riesgos que toma, se conformara con un típico "final feliz". No me malentiendan, es bonito y esperanzador, pero se siente como si todos los problemas que te planteaba el juego se arreglaran por arte de magia. No creo que el final por sí mismo arruiné una fantástica experiencia, pero si me encuentro decepcionado con este final.

Con todo eso en mente (y que muy probablemente mi gusto por el juego sea mayor que la calidad en si del mismo) debo decir que al final Iconoclasts, con todo y sus notorios problemas, me gustó mucho. Su historia y sus interesantes personajes hacen que valga la pena dejar a un lado los malos momentos.

Lo recomiendo.

This is another one of those, "Waited ten years, but it was worth it," games.

Iconoclasts' main appeal is in its gorgeous pixel art, which satisfies everything a fan of the art style could ever desire.  But don't make the mistake of thinking that's all it has to offer.  Sandberg implements ingenius game design that some AAA developers could only dream of comprehending, offering unique puzzles, clever level design, intuitive combat, and even a crafting system to reward players who like to explore and collect items.

Iconoclasts hooks you with its art and design, but keeps you playing for the storyline.  Don't let the game's cheerful appearance deceive you - Iconoclasts explores the darker side of people's emotions, and you will often find yourself empathizing with the immersive and well developed cast of characters as they struggle to fight their inner demons.  Sandberg's writing provides a realistic narrative on the illness of depression, as well as demonstrating examples of the human psyche such as emotional abuse, the corruption of power, and PTSD.

But even in its darkest moments, it reminds us that there is always one thing: Hope.  And for hope to prevail, all it needs is for people to try to help each other whenever they can - and maybe also someone who knows how to use a wrench.

40341702.review:
Iconoclasts is definitely an interesting game. A more linear look at the metroidvania genre that manages pacing and story beats very well. And for being one of the few games to make me shed a tear, I think I'll break down everything I like and dislike about it.

Regardless of what I bring up here, my final point is that the game is more than worth the purchase, and that maybe we'll get more great games from this studio.

Let's start with the positives.

Movement mechanics are incredibly fluid for the most part. Robin moves at a quick and enjoyable pace, and with some practice it becomes easy to range around the environments rapidly.

Combat feels rewarding, while still making outright avoidance an option in the sections where you'll mostly just be passing through while backtracking.

Every weapon feels powerful and useful, even to the endgame. The three fire modes each find their niche in combat and allow for a flexible combat environment.

The art style is absolutely gorgeous and even the backgrounds feel flowing and immersive. That's not to mention the depth of unique animations each character has while each one still reads clearly.

The characters are both powerful and charismatic, each in their own way. I never found myself bored with their antics and speech, even in the larger expository monologues. You'll easily come to fall in love with many of the recurring cast.

Bosses are unique and enjoyable, tending to be a test of whatever mechanics you've had to learn to reach them, all while allowing some flexibility in style of combat. You can fight them in the obvious way, or you can sometimes find sneaky ways to deal large amounts of damage and finish the fight quickly.

The story is nicely laid out and paced. It doesn't frontload very much, and allows you to learn about the history and lore at your own pace, only pointing out the more important bits explicitly where it may be necessary to progress.


And now my few quibbles and dislikes.

While most of the movement is enjoyable, the ledge grab mechanic is very clunky feeling compared to the fluidity of the other forms of movement.

The weapons each have their own charged shot form, but I find that they don't feel like they charge properly. Sometimes I'll charge a shot and rarely still fire the uncharged version.

Robin as a character is interesting, but I don't think she benefits much from being a mostly silent protagonist.

The map is large, and unfortunately, with the limited backgrounds, it can be easy to find yourself wandering in circles if you're not checking the map regularly.

I have specific gripes with the prison escape segment in the tower, as keeping track of where things are in it's map is tricky, as well as a general lack of any kind of signposting, resulting in a lot of running around trying everything you can until you finally figure it out.

Funnily enough, although the opening segments have very well incorporated tutorial parts, signposting in the second half of the game drops off almost completely. This may not sound like a problem, but after being subtly led around for the first half, exploring these gorgeous maps, getting lost with no easy way to figure out where to go next can be frustrating.


Despite all this, I find the game very enjoyable, so much so, in fact, that I accidentally stayed up way past when I should have gone to sleep one night and spent my entire day at work yawning the next day. I then completed it the next day and proceded to write this review. Overall, I'd give it an eight out of ten. My few issues with the game keep it from a nine and breaking my heart near the end keeps it from the extra point to make it a ten.


TLDR It's a good game, with great mechanics (lol) a lovely soundtrack, and can be finished in about a day if you start early.
