Now this was a rollercoaster-ride of sorts. From the get-go, I knew this game was for me. Metroidvania-platformer mainly reminding me of Cave Story+ - which isn't a bad thing. You run around and shoot stuff with your gun and get other guns and so far so Cave Story. Then I realized that this game is very very puzzle-focused, which I found weird at first but quite endearing after that. Almost every room incorporates a puzzle and even some of the enemies have you thinking how to defeat them. Oh and the bosses - they are amazingly well crafted and often presented as a giant puzzle in and of themselves. Gameplaywise you are getting what's on the cover of the box - a solid puzzle-focused metroidvania experience. 

Now why was this a rollercoaster-ride? For me, because this game starts out very, you know, happy. Everything is colorful and fluffy and just uplifting. And while this overall tone doesn't change completely, there are moments, that just really go dark in one or the other way - and I loved that. I had conflicts with the actions I was taking even though those actions, narratively speaking, were just and logical. That, to me, was an amazing feeling that still kind of lingers with me. Sometimes there was too much talking for my taste, but ultimately it made for some well crafted characters, that made me enjoy the story more, than a lot of other metroidvanias tend to do. 

As a metroidvania - it is a solid game. The sense of exploration doesn't hold up to something like [b]Hollow Knight[/b], but the puzzle focused areas are an interesting fresh take. Moving around isn't as fun as, say, [b]Ori and the Blind Forest[/b], but the diverse cast of characters delivers on another level. So, as a metroidvania, it is very solid.

As a game, genre not accounted for, it is great. It got me hooked from the very beginning and as of writing this I'm closing the gap from 92% completion to 100% and I still enjoy every second, feel decently challenged (playing on harder mode) and am just having fun.
This is a game, that deserves your support and your time :)

39727075.review:
This month was so rich with its games and I can't be happy enough about it. Let's say, I had already a lot of fun this month and it's only a start of the year with lots of good stuff coming. Majority of these games were indie projects of course and I spent a lot of time exploring all of them.

Frankly speaking, I really respect ambitious people. It's something I really adore and can't stop admiring the way they carry their ideas through the whole life without even thinking of dropping it, meeting problems and other obstacles and dealing with them. I know a lot of people in my life, who has a lot of "cool ideas' which ends only on paper. When it comes to real life and to that moment where you have to really do something - they fail and never recover. Because it's simply much easier to talk, rather then create and show everyone, that we all live here on planet Earth for a purpose.

Last time we had this ambitious project created by only one person, was Stardew Valley and it was simply stunning, brilliant and definitely a perfect example what a great work should look like in the end. Only one person, with a support of his loving girlfriend created something that looks like an enormous game made by a big team with a strong support. It's clearly fantastic and so damn motivational!

And now we have Iconoclasts. Another game that was in development for 10 years and was only created by one one person. Last 7 years Joakim Sandberg was spending all his time on developing Iconoclasts. And now, when it's fully released, we can enjoy this masterpiece to its fullest. He came to the idea for this game back in 2007, but only had a chance to start working on it 3 years later. Like I said before, it was a really big and enormous work for one person, not only because of how big this game is, but also because of the ambitiousness of the project. 

The game plot sets in a world, where everything depends on a fuel, called "ivory", which counts as a sacred one and used for fueling machines. All these workers, who are responsible for fueling these machines are really important in this world and are counted almost as a priests, as well. It's really interesting that this game has a mix of this interesting idea, story telling, puzzles, arcade mechanics and metroidvania elements. Joakim never had a scenario, before he started to work on this game, he was writing everything during the work. When he started working on this game, he was at his early-20th and the whole game shoulda be much more funnier, full of these easy vibes, without any deep meanings and strong characters. But the more he worked on it and became older, the more darker the whole story became. 

And you can clearly feel it while playing the game. It starts kinda slow, in meditate manner and then it turns to a serious story about growing up. About people in your surrounding and the way you change through the communication with them and helping them around in any possible way you can. It's something you don't care about when you are 20, and all this understanding comes to you when you are older and much more experienced person. I have these feeling, that Joakim put something really personal in this story and its up to you either you wanna feel it or just run through the game and move to the next one asap. 

I am really enjoying this masterpiece. Everything I see on a display deserves hours to look on it and explore and just enjoy every pixel, because when you see something like this, made with love from the bottom of you soul and heart, you simply want it to last as longer as possible. All these puzzles you need to solve with your wrench are so enjoyable and they never seem hard or boring to you, I can count it as a major plus to this game, you will never have this feeling like "oh jeesus christ I don't get what they want from me, damn this game, I am out" and rage quit, no, its not about this game. It's simply about the charming adventures and life questions that Robin (main female protagonist) tries to find answers on.

Mr. Joakim Sandberg, if there is any chance that you will see my review here on steam, I just wanted to say thank you for your enormous work and let you know that your hard work should be taken as an incredible example for anyone, who starts something new and experience hard times during development. I admire you a lot and wish you only the best in the future, will be looking forward to your next games and I believe that you are one of these amazing creative and talented persons who should lead the gaming community on the way to its quality and responsibility for their products.

To sum everything up.
You should grab this game if you:

+ Indie lover like me :)
+ Feel like playing something really special, a masterpiece BIG game, created by ONE person
+ Enjoy puzzles in arcade platformer games 
+ Put story telling and character development higher than anything itself.
+ Just like quality games with polished design 
+ Like metroidvania elements
+ Want to create a next big game, and you need a motivation, this one will definitely blows your mind.

You should pass if you:

- Well, to be honest it's kinda hard for me to talk about cons in this game. I guess, you should not grab this game if you don't like pixel art and arcade platformer games are not your genre in general.               

Enjoy! And I need to go back to playing this gem :)

I'm one of those folks who only just learned about this game and its seven or so years of development and I'm damned glad that I did.

From the very beginning it looks great, plays great and the quirky little mechanics though not incredibly varied are just enough to satisfy you the whole the way through.

The narrative, I'll admit I wasn't 100% sold on at first. "Alright, what a cute, quirky little adventure we're embarking on with these unusual characters!" I did say. Little did I realize that as the story went on and the dialogue (which is mostly awesome and/or hilarious) that it would eventually suck me in and keep me gripped until the final screen of the game.

The only POSSIBLE downside if you're a gamer who requires some serious challenge in their diet is that you won't be getting that till you unlock challenge mode and even then possibly only with the optional bosses (also fantastic).

What the game may not provide in challenge it definitely provides in fun though. The levels are fun with sensational tunes, the puzzles are NOT completely irritating and the bosses all incredibly satisfying and intense to battle.

How history view Iconoclasts I'm unsure but for the moment it'd be a shame for anyone with an appreciation for gaming  to not have this in their library. Fantastic work.

Maybe two hours isn't enough for a review, but that's how much I played before I just... quit the game when it wasn't fun.

It starts off strong, really good sense of art. Great music, gorgeous animation, it leads in well. But as soon as you're in control the magic starts wearing off, because everything about the actual platforming feels just a bit too clunky, the platforming feels a bit too slow, and there are too many enemies that just... aren't fun to fight, they're tedious to fight instead, especially when the game gives them weak points where seemingly the exact same attack doesn't actually nail it every time. With no sign of what the issue was. 

So the first warning sign was when I started just running past enemies, taking my lumps and not giving a damn.

Then there's the upgrade system where... I just grabbed some upgrades because I had the slots, not because I cared about having the upgrades. They felt forgettable and I don't think they ever made any difference to me.

There's stuff like dialogue prompts for YOU PICKED UP A THING! and similar take just a bit too long before you can banish them.

There's all the OTHER dialogue which I primarily don't give a damn about. Because it's mostly NPC's stomping around and being very loud and... I just don't care about them. Yes certainly they're angry and they might have opinions. But I don't care about them. None of them are particularly charming or interesting. And sometimes they seem to switch characterization in the span of two minutes.

Then there's stuff like introducing an entirely new mechanic... IN A BOSS FIGHT. Which is just bad game design no matter how you slice it. Especially when the boss fight itself is already pretty obtuse and nothing you do seems to have any effect on the boss, damage-wise.

It feels like no one ever playtested this game except for the developer himself, so it was made only for his tastes, with only his feedback, and with a ton of things that made sense to him, because he made it, because he designed it, but which never really makes much sense to other people. Which is a shame, because art? Good. Music? Good. Everything else? Flop.

I'd recommend not getting this, I doubt even patching will end up resolving its issues, because they're not bug issues, they're design issues.

At that time I was unaware how long the game was in the oven, so there was no hype that would maybe influence me at the start, so as I explored the world, it became clear to me how this was such a great homage to its old school predecessors and a star among a sea of 2d games, that most of the time don't deliver. 

[h1]Prologue[/h1]
You as a player play with with Robin an illegal mechanic , our female protagonist, who is trying to help better the world against the wishes of the tyrannical and oppressive, "One Concern" a religious cult tied to the world's technology who controls the world and in turn the people's freedom. During our journey we going to meet new characters and getting to know different locations ( underwater locations, desert and so on).

All in All a solid experience. Fun, with good puzzles and great boss fights. Big enough to fill your 2d appetite.

39712627.review:
First and foremost, Iconoclasts is an amazing achievement. For someone to single-handedly create every aspect of a sizeable game (design, programming, graphics, audio) by themselves over 7 years, and for it all to have this much polish, is nothing short of impressive and inspiring.

But this fact would not matter much if Iconoclasts wasn't a good game. Thankfully, it is. There's two things that to me are particularily noteworthy about the game:

One: Incredible, creative boss fights. If you've played konjak's previous game, Noitu Love 2, then you'll know what to expect, but the stuff on display in Iconoclasts surpasses even that. Here's just a short list of the type of boss fights you can expect: Innovative, almost puzzle-like experiences. Simple, but narratively significant moments of tension. Tough-as-nails and hugely satisfying brawls. Surprising and over-the-top encounters. Seriously, if boss fights often happen to be one of your favourite things about video games, then grab Iconoclasts. It will absolutely deliver.

Two: This one is big. Iconoclasts is an action-heavy game with explosions and fights and yet... the player character does not turn into a mass murderer over the course of the game. The majority of enemies you fight are robots or monsters inspired by flora and fauna. So, the first time a human enemy dies, it's actually a big deal. The character responsible breaks down over it, even though this enemy had just tried to kill them and you. Shortly after this scene, you have to clear an area of human enemies. My initial concern was that this would just make the previous scene feel silly. But, as it turns out, you only knock them out! Combat works normally, but you don’t kill. Later, playing as a different character, you do end up killing human enemies (or you can run past them, if you prefer). But for this character, narratively, it made more sense, than it did for the main character. This is what we need more of! Not to derail this review, but I recently played Rise of the Tomb Raider and all its attempts at making Lara a relatable, realistic character don’t matter, because she is just mowing down enemies left and right without a second thought or any self-awareness about it. Iconoclasts however proves you can have action gameplay without the carnage or forcing non-lethal stealth alternatives onto the gameplay and that is just really incredible to me.

Also noteworthy is the game's strong focus and dedication to its characters. Although there is no voice acting, the playful nature in which the text is animated or variated in size, as well as the strong characterization on display both work together to give Iconoclasts a uniquely memorable and distinct cast. I can't remember coming across a Metroidvania-style game where the characters and story had this huge of a focus, and that was really refreshing. Also, it's pretty darn funny at times. It's not a comedy game, but when it makes jokes, they land.

Although, upon namedropping the Metroidvania-term I'll have to say that the feeling of exploration that these kinds of games often exhibit felt somewhat absent here. That's not to say that that's a bad thing, or that the beautifully illustrated and lively game world was boring to explore, but the focus felt more on the how of navigation rather than on the where of navigation. By which I mean to say, to progress you'll often have to solve very light puzzles. Rather than having a very open layout with multiple roadblocks clearly requiring new abilities on your part and backtracking a lot, Iconoclasts is very streamlined. Unless you're going for 100% completion, you're probably unlikely to revisit the various areas in the game. You're also not picking up a huge number of different abilities, you're picking up different weapons (and different upgrades for them), but ultimately you only have four available (counting the wrench). You do also gather crafting ingredients for so-called tweaks. It took me until pretty late into the game to actually start utilizing these tweaks seriously, so to me personally, they felt a little bit like an afterthought. They don't add much to the game, but once you realize that specific combinations may give you big advantages in various boss fights, you'll likely find it to be a pretty fun system to play around with.

There's also minor nitpicks to be had, such as the mechanic for throwing boxes being a little fiddly or it not always being clear on what to do next (whether it's how to fight a boss or where to go next), but I never felt truly stuck and in need of external help. Additionally, although the plot itself felt less interesting than the characters to me, the strong focus on the characters and the intriguing world-building still meant I was curious to see what would happen next. These issues may weigh more strongly for other players, but to me they in no way detracted from my enjoyment of the game.

To summarize: Iconoclasts is a polished and beautifully illustrated game, full of incredible boss fights and fun, simple navigational puzzles. It has a uniquely strong focus on its characters' personal shortcomings and challenges, paired with imaginative world-building. I highly recommend it.

39712454.review:
[h1] The Metroidvania Review[/h1]

[url=https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1UYUeyCwoiaS1_c64gwmMN-n1xKptM9u4EKBGXS257y0/edit#gid=1723820084] Scored Summary[/url] |  |                          [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/30503887/] Subscribe to our Curator	[/url]


When a game promises to convey a "personal story about faith" and "purpose", I buckle up for the risk of a train wreck. With Iconoclasts however, I not only got to see a wonderfully mature and thoughtful series of ideas and unique situations, but as the game escalated into its climax it ended up being a wild ride of surprising experiences. The game has a high focus on Spatial Reasoning puzzles over your typical combat/platforming common in the genre, and because of that I'm not positive every Metroidvania fan is going to enjoy this particular cup of tea. But if you DO enjoy these kinds of puzzles, along with some excellent (but also puzzle heavy) combat, and a JRPG style of story-telling, Iconoclasts may in fact be the best game in the entire genre for you.

I'd like to emphasize the story aspect first, because in my mind that is one of the the primary draws of the game. The way it is told is nothing short of masterful. Robin is a silent protagonist, and Mario RPG style she pantomimes most of what she's thinking - and like Mario RPG it's incredibly cute and entertaining. I'm not normally a fan of the Silent Protagonist, but the decision serves the game well to magnify the game's fantastic supporting cast. There's a lot of quirkiness throughout the narrative that helps to keep it fun, but at no point did I feel like any of the game's villains were non-threatening as a result of it. The game celebrates life with its presentation while keeping a tone of tension in a remarkable balancing act that places Iconoclasts high on the list of great storytelling in video games of any genre. It tackles themes that are controversial in a philosophical way, reminding me of games like Xenogears, particularly on the topic of faith. It cautions against blind adherence to dogma without necessarily discounting the benefits of religion - leaving a lot of conclusions about the very real feelings conveyed up to the player to interpret. It's the kind of story that I could write essays about in analysis, and I really don't feel like I'm overselling it by saying that.

But with that said, there is also a very clear gameplay focus. The game begins with no cutscenes, and provides only signs that explain the game's controls through the conveyance of pictures. The tried and true method of teaching the player through gameplay is tackled magnificently from the very start.  Bosses begin their AI pattern gradually, showing off each of their attacks individually before they ramp the challenge by mixing attacks together or speeding up. The puzzles too put each of your new abilities to the test as the game progresses.

And it all works together thematically as well. Puzzles involve moving platforms around using your wrench to turn bolts and wheels, often permanently changing the landscape, which gives this game a feeling of everything unfolding gradually as you fix the worlds problems. As you unfold the story and mysteries of the game it's like a puzzle box where each layer reveals something new and often surprising. Even the combat is deceptively simple at first, giving me the impression that this was indeed a puzzle game above all else - until the stakes got to the point that I was facing enemies that tested me as much as some of the greatest encounters in the genre.

Iconoclasts is nearly perfect, but that isn't to say I don't have a few nitpicks. The music is good but not quite as memorable as some of its Indie Contemporaries - which is less of a fault and more that the standard has been set so high in that regard. The tweak system is interesting but I feel like the execution could use a little work. The metroidvania exploration element of this game has you finding one of four crafting materials that function as fractions of these equippable tweaks that affect your stats in specific ways. If you get hit in combat, you lose one of your tweaks, which you can recharge by collecting enemy drops - it's sort of like Cave Story. Unlike Cave Story however many of the tweaks are less attractive for combat and more attractive for puzzle solving or more exploration. If your equipment is focused on anything other than combat then the risk of losing your tweaks becomes less of a source of tension, almost making the system feel pointless. There are a few key tweaks that are especially useful when fighting, but even on the game's harder mode I never felt like I was desperately trying to keep my energy levels at maximum as part of my survival; my incentive to avoid being hit was strictly about not dying. The near irrelevance of the tweaks is especially important because they are the only reward for exporation.

But I consider complaining about the tweaks a nitpick at best. Exploration is rewarding in Iconoclasts because it is fun, and there are also challenging bonuses available to the most stalwart achiever in that category of gameplay. Even if my only reward for exploration were bits of poo, I'd still do it because it is enjoyable.

Which sums up Iconoclasts in a single word; "Enjoyable." I'd add the important "thought provoking" and "challenging" to the descriptor, but I know for some people the pure joy this game provided for me is enough for my report.

If you like the three things I mentioned in the first paragraph, that is, JRPG style storytelling, Metroidvanias, and Spatial Reasoning puzzles, get this game. It may be the best purchase you make this year.

5 out of 5

39711876.review:
Overall I think this is a flawed masterpiece. I appreciate its existence immensly, but there are some questionable stuff. Below I'll just list spoiler free observations that would've guided me in buying the game if I didn't own it already.

The game looks very, very good. In most other games, especially 2D ones, you'd see about 10 % as many unique animations per character as this game has, and they'd be 10 % as polished. The cutscenes are majestic creations. It's easy to see why this game took so long to make. Whether or not you think it was worth the time is another question (I do, for the record).

I'm not sure I'd call it a metroidvania, but that's semantics, so to explain: the progression is not so much about getting powerups that allow you to get to new areas. You do that a few times, but mostly new roads are unlocked arbitrarily due to story progression. This is neither good nor bad but some people with specific ideas of what they want from a metroidvania might be disappointed.

It has significantly more emphasis on puzzle platforming than on action. This is not an action game in the same sense as Noitu Love 2, or Momodora, or even Cave Story. Most of the enemies you fight are puzzles themselves, where you need to wait for the right moment or parry them. You can usually just run past enemies though, or facetank them (even on hard). This too is neither good nor bad, but I really enjoy action focused games so I was a bit sad. At the very end comes some really well made battles that made me think "god damn, why couldn't the whole game be this focused on raw action?" I'll guess I'll have to replay Noitu Love 2 for that.

The puzzles are decent. Despite how many there are, only a few made me feel "oh, that's clever". Mostly the solution is fairly obvious and from there it's just a matter of execution. Most of the actually clever ones were to reach optional chests, which is fine I guess.

The optional chests unlock stuff that didn't really excite me that much. It's basically a crafting system that lets you build modifiers that buff you slightly, but when you take damage they power down and you must build them up again (think Cave Story). While the upgrade system itself didn't wow me, I feel like the optional chests were important for the game, and they had to be filled with something.

I usually enjoy when games don't direct you too much, but man, sometimes I got really confused during this game. Sometimes Joakim understood that people would get confused - so much so that he added fireflies that guided your way. And then sometimes those fireflies didn't go away when they were supposed to, so they began guiding you the wrong way.  Once in a while, you'll get a ?-mark on the map to show you the way, and to be honest despite my usual preference I actually think those should've been around all of the time.

The reason you might be confused is because, as I mentioned earlier, progression is usually not tied to what skills you've obtained, but through generic locks or story progression. The story progression part is super, duper arbitrary. A place with a closed door might suddenly have opened, or a cave is cleared from rubble, or some dude has appeared where previously there was nothing. The for me unintuitive level design is probably the only thing I feel [i]decidedly[/i] negative towards in the game.

I found the music passable. I don't remember any songs. Despite it being okay, I do feel that if Joakim should've gotten help with any aspect, it should've been the music. He has spent such tremendous effort polishing cutscenes and building atmosphere that the music just falls lightyears short. I respect his decision to hold firm to the "one man army" thing he has going, but music is [i]so[/i] important for cinematic experiences, and I wish he had swallowed his pride and done what was best for the game here.

I really liked the worldbuilding, and the characters. If you don't like the characters you won't like the story, because the story is about the characters and the plot itself is just a framework for them expressing themselves. There are some mysteries uncovered about the world as you go, but to me it didn't feel like these revelations were the core of the story.

To me, the massive reliance on characters to drive the plot is one of the key things that make me appreciate this game so, so much. I can confidently say that the experience in that regard has been completely unique compared to all other games I've played. Even though the plot moves more sideways than forward, it's okay because so much effort has been put into making characters talking to each other interesting.

This does mean though that if you're not into banter, or you dislike the characters, the story is probably stillborn for you. You get a good idea of how it'll all play out within the 2 hour refund window.

The game took me 10.5 hours to beat on "harder" mode. My playtime on Steam is higher because I kept the game running a lot in pause menu. Replayability is limited, in my opinion.

All in all, I'd say this game is a superb cinematic experience, has uniquely character driven storytelling, is a decent puzzle platformer, and an okay action game. Honestly it tickles about the same spots as an Uncharted game for me, but I personally vastly prefer the characters and setting in this game.

All its flaws aside, to people like me I highly recommend playing the game.

“Иконоборцы” разрабатывались семь лет. Даже больше, если вести летоисчисление от древнейших концепций. И сделаны они одним человеком. Данные факты ничего не говорят о качестве игры. Просто когда автор вкладывает в произведение столько времени и сил, они становятся практически неотделимы друг от друга. 

Это игра от начала и до конца режиссерская. Отражающая интересы своего создателя, пронизанная его индивидуальностью. Игра Юакима Сандберга о Юакиме Сандберге.  

Начинается она в основном безвредно. Первые уровни – бесцельное путешествие через яркие природные зоны, полные странного зверья и занятных задачек. Но вскоре зверушек сменяют вооруженные люди. Природу – военные инсталляции и секретные базы. История медленно закипает, делается интенсивнее и мрачнее. Игра взрослеет и стареет вместе с автором. Становится умнее и заумнее. Ехиднее и черствее. 

Из названия следует, что темой должно быть некое иконоборчество. Практическое или духовное. Не сотвори себе кумира и тому подобное. 
И действительно, в гротескном мире игры идет борьба между двумя религиозными фракциями. Тоталитарная позитивистская теократия и её церковь летающего макаронного монстра противостоят агрессивно пацифисткой коммуне хиппи, поклоняющихся матери-земле через безудержное размножение. Организованная пропаганда против добровольного невежества. Обе стороны мягко говоря не правы, причем совершенно объективно. В представлении так же участвует россыпь фанатиков, маньяков и просто нестабильных личностей. Например,  просветленный пророк равенства и братства, действующий по принципу: “В бараний рог согну, в порошок сотру! У меня враз все станут счастливыми!”
  
Единственная, кого эта драма не трогает – главная героиня, механик Робин. Осознанно или по наивности она игнорирует политику, религию, конфликты, ненависть и страдания. С неё всё как с гуся вода.
 
Сценарий игры писался по ходу разработки. И это чувствуется. Несколько событий зажигают сюжетный фитиль. Все остальное – цепочка реакций и импровизаций. Причем к Робин это относится в первую очередь. Да, она моральный компас истории, но не её двигатель. Бегство-спасение-бегство-спасение – вот её сюжетная линия. Почему она не выражает своих желаний, не обсуждает происходящее? Если не способна – это не интересно. Если не желает – как минимум спорно. Другой вариант - она уже пережила тяжелейшую травму, и новые удары судьбы её просто не трогают.
 
Но, скорее всего, в этом и выражается её иконоборчество. Она механик. Она любит чинить. Что именно – неважно. Вещи. Людей. Планету. Робин выходит из дому и идет помогать окружающим. Что бы ни стояло на пути, она лишь потешно хмурится, выпячивает грудь и сжимает кулаки. 
“Мой гаечный ключ – это моя душа! Он завернет планету в правильном направлении!” 
А после выполненной работы можно идти домой и с чистой совестью ложиться спать. 

Робин – молчаливый протагонист. Она не немая, просто скромная и тихая. И её молчание трактуется каждым встречным, как приглашение к душевным откровениям. 
Персонажи много делают, чтобы выразить свои чувства. Но еще больше о них говорят. Многие постоянно находятся на грани нервного срыва. Или за гранью. А когда два грозовых фронта истерики сталкиваются, это выливается в бурю иррационального гнева, взаимных обвинений и воплей капсом.
  
Все участники событий крайне несовершенны. И большинство из них предпочитают деградировать, а не развиваться. Неотвратимо летят вниз по заданной траектории. Кроме того, Автор любит наказывать своих детей за грехи и недостатки. Он жестокий демиург. Если персонаж совершил проступок, ему за это десятикратно воздастся. Даже те герои, которые движутся по пути становления и исправления, не могут избежать его роковой кары.  

Местами сюжет пронизан убийственным фатализмом. И идет все от персонажей. Кто-то проповедует самоуничижение. Кто-то упивается эгоизмом. Многие твердят, что поступают правильно. Но правильность отличается от человека к человеку. Один говорит: “Ради общего блага.” Другой: “Сила в предназначении.” Третий: “Раз я победил, значит, я добрый!” 

Но есть в бочке нигилизма и ложка позитива. Есть юмор, порой очень удачный. А весь этот ансамбль страдальцев и глупцов существует, чтобы испытать героиню. Она ничего не говорит и ни на чем не настаивает. Просто делает свое дело. И делает его хорошо. Она обладает силой и принимает осознанное решение не применять её во зло. Блаженны кроткие, ибо унаследуют землю. Типа того.
  
По мнению самого Сандберга сюжет должен быть интегрирован в игровой процесс. Но проще сказать, чем сделать. Чем дальше, тем больше история тянет одеяло на себя. Тем не менее, дизайн уровней и геймплей здесь продуманы до мелочей. А потом тщательно изучены, перепроверены и продуманы еще десяток раз.

Робин умеет бегать, прыгать, стрелять тремя типами снарядов, завинчивать гайки, драться гаечным ключом, заряжать его электричеством, скользить по проводам, разбивать под собой каменные блоки. И при этом безупречно управляется даже с клавиатуры.

Игра последовательно выкручивает сложность. Но не увеличивает количество врагов или их запас здоровья. Вместо этого меняется их поведение, тактика, слабые места. Иногда меняется так радикально и неожиданно, что остается только разводить руками.  

В Иконоборцах есть место для исследований, сражений и поиска сокровищ. Но в основе своей эта игра – пазл. Ключ к победе в любом испытании – понять, что вообще происходит. Даже к самой безумной, адреналиновой схватке стоит относиться, как к головоломке. В первую очередь это относится к боссам. В игре их больше 20, и никто не хочет драться по правилам. Все козыряют багажом необычных фишек и трюков. По разному двигаются, по разному атакуют и защищаются. Далеко не всегда слабое место врага можно определить с первого взгляда. Простейшая загадка, изложенная игроку недостаточно внятно, может вогнать человека в ступор и довести до изнеможения. К добру или к худу, но фрустрация – часть здешнего игрового процесса.
 
Я несколько раз безнадежно застревал в самых невинных ситуациях, не имея ни малейшего понятия о том, чего игра от меня хочет. Но ответ неизменно оказывался простым, очевидным и естественным. У меня никогда не возникало желания обвинить игру в неадекватности. Но другие люди могут засыпать её претензиями, и по-своему тоже будут правы. 

Иконоборцы – это плод невероятного, почти болезненного упрямства. Результат сотен попыток и бесчисленных ошибок. 
Это игра спорная. Но по-другому в принципе быть не могло. Её недостатки – не от нехватки мысли, страсти, старания. А от явного переизбытка.  
Её автору не пришлось идти на компромиссы. Он все сделал так, как хотел. 
Попробуйте. Может, окажется, что ваши вкусы совпадают.

Avant de commencer à donner mon avis sur Iconoclasts, je vais d’abord vous parler de Joakim Sandberg, aka Konjak.

Quand j’étais jeune, enfin plus jeune… 
Bref… vers 2008, 2009. Je suis tombé sur Chalk par hasard qui est un petit jeu dudit Konjak. Petit shoot très original et bien sympathique qui m’avait bien plu à l’époque. J’ai commencé à chercher des informations sur son auteur et je suis tombé sur Legend of Princess. Et là, je dois bien admettre que j’ai été sous le charme. Imaginer un fan game Zelda, un action/plateforme 2D avec un scrolling horizontal, beau, ultra-nerveux et respectant son univers avec une touche de folie et une musique bien sentie. Il est de plus gratuit et vous n’avez AUCUNE EXCUSE de ne pas y jouer surtout au vu la qualité du soft.

Dès lors, j’ai attendu ses projets avec un certain intérêt et même si je n’ai pas encore joué à Noitu Love 2 que par le biais d’une démo. Je dois dire que j’ai bien suivi les projets auxquels il a participé sans m’en rendre compte. Étant donné qu’il a travaillé pour WayForward sur des jeux comme Contra 4, la série Shantae et Mighty Switch Force dans l’animation de sprites 2D!.

Je vous laisse donc imaginer mon impatience de toucher Iconoclasts. Et je ne suis pas déçu.

Tout d’abord, sachez que Konjak a sorti une version « antérieure » à Iconoclasts. Elle porte le nom d’Ivory Springs qui parcourt assez fidèlement le début du jeu et s’arrête après le 2eme boss du jeu.


Voilà pour le préambule. Et sinon, Iconoclasts c’est bien ? Et c’est quoi en fait ?

Iconoclasts est un action/plateforme typé « metroidvania » en 2D on l’on contrôle Robin, une mécanicienne qui va avoir beaucoup de problèmes avec le régime en place. De fil en aiguille, elle parcourra une histoire des plus agréables avec des sujets variés comme l’écologie, la religion ou l’industrialisation à outrance. Questionnant son lecteur au fil de l’aventure. Des liens seront tissés entre les protagonistes créant une empathie que j’ai rarement vue dans un jeu vidéo. C’est simple, tous les personnages sont attachants sauf un ou deux et l’histoire contée est des plus soignées.

Les graphismes sont au top, et l’on sent que Joakim Sandberg a bossé comme un taré sur le design. Il n’y a qu’à voir les décors, les personnages et les animations pour se rendre compte du travail abattu par le monsieur. Alors oui, on peut chipoter sur certains graphismes, sur des animations un peu « brutes » mais on est quand même devant un travail orfèvre. Un bijou visuel qui manque de quelques touches de-ci de-là pour parfaire une l’œuvre déjà sublime.

Le game design est très bon, le personnage répond au doigt et à l’œil et propose une grande gamme de mouvements ainsi que des améliorations bien. Les ennemis bougent bien et ont des patterns très agréables et novateurs pour certains. Les boss sont un délice, ils sont beaux, variés, différents dans la manière de les affronter, difficiles comme il faut mais pas insurmontables.

Mais je note des moments chiants comme d’affronter les troufions de base du projet qui sont une plaie ou la maniabilité qui manque de souplesse comme une esquive offerte avec une amélioration qui s’utilise avec BAS + ATTACK. Ce qui est contre mécanique (le lier à une touche spécifique aurait été plus intelligent par exemple). Le tout reste très jouable, mais j’aurai souhaité plus de rigueur. Que l’on soit d’accord, c’est toujours du chipotage. ♥

Par contre, le level design est parfait. Le monde regorge de combat, de secret et d’énigme sans jamais lasser le joueur. En 15 heures, je n’ai jamais eu la sensation de faire 2 fois la même chose. Chaque zone à son level design et chaque objet débloque plusieurs capacités, je prendrai la clé à molette comme exemple qui sert à de nombreuses choses, mais les autres items ne sont pas en reste. Bref, c’est LE point fort du jeu au-delà du reste qui touche déjà le sublime.

La musique est bonne dans son ensemble, certaines sortent du lot et sont vraiment excellentes. Les bruitages sont globalement bien choisis.

Bref, Iconoclasts est un bijou que je ne saurai que trop vous conseiller. Pour ma part, je ferai sûrement une « new game + » ainsi que pour découvrir le boss caché du jeu.

Alright, I gave this go on Harder Mode and 100%'d the game. I can't say if the standard difficulty would resolve some of my problems, so bear that in mind.


Iconoclasts is a very good game, with excellent music and art. The story is pretty decent, as well. Its gameplay is probably the element with the most flaws - with very good ideas and platforming sometimes made frustrating with poor telegraphing.

Let's break it down: The exploration aspect of Iconoclasts is solid - the secrets are well hidden, and fun to discover. However, there were plenty of moments where my character was TOO responsive when making more delicate maneuvers (I hate the dang ladders because they wont let me jump up them by continually holding up + jump) *shakes fist*.

Combat with standard enemies is alright, but it was rarely something I enjoyed outright (beyond a few circumstances where the enemies and room worked together exceptionally well). None of your weapons let you take a lazy Metroid-esque approach and just spam shots everywhere that murder everything. Even the last weapon has a limitation with its cooldown, which juuuuuust kept it away from being real fun. 

This was likely intentional, and I could see the logic behind it, but as I said - rarely did the standard combat catch my interest.

On the other hand, the boss fights deserve a special look because they're good. Not great, but good. They are almost always frantic, often have a unique mechanic, and very learnable patterns. HOWEVER, those unique mechanics and patterns would often collide in an ugly mess where I couldn't quite figure out what the heck is going on. There were many boss patterns that I would just attempt to brute force through, and spam attacks instead of dodging.


The developer gets bonus points for not relying on super obvious and offensive tropes in the story. . :)

I'd give this game a B+ (which I think is rather good) for an overall excellent production for but a few rough edges. Get ye this game if you want a metroidvania with a stylish presentation, crazy boss fights, and a story that knows how to veer back and forth between comedy and drama.

TLDR: Some strangeness in the writing and a number of jaw-grindingly frustrating gameplay sections didn't stop me from plowing through this game in a couple of sittings and unequivocally adoring it.  It's gorgeous, it's fun, the characters are great (Agent Black has slipped into my top five favourite videogame antagonists, muttering about a headache) and the game's setpiece boss battles are endlessly inventive.

For people who care about my largely nitpicky cons, I'll elaborate below.

The writing was weirdly inconsistent - part of it was a sense of 'lost in translation', with some sentences being oddly structured or difficult to parse, but there were other issues, like how the plot felt like it wanted to make a point, but raised so many subjects I wasn't sure what that point was, and the bizarre variances in tone between the dark af central plot and goofy, quirky side character dialogue.  This wasn't a big deal for me, I'm the kind of person for whom plot is secondary to character (and the characters in this game are brilliant, at least the central ones are) but this might nag at you if you're a story nut.

The issue that *did* wind up bothering me, however, is that the game is fond of wildly sharp difficulty spikes, both in combat encounters and in terms of puzzle complexity.  The controls simply didn't feel tight enough for some of what the game was demanding from me, and that was compounded by incredibly demanding timing required on a number of puzzles whose completion was mandatory to advance the story, and a couple of encounters late in the game that subject you to an overwhelming volume of opposition, demanding that you carefully jump and weave between multiple damage-on-contact hostiles in an almost bullet-hell like fashion.  I don't object to that kind of gameplay, but given it wasn't seen in the game before that point and the ever so slightly mushy controls, it led to a number of moments of facedesk-level frustration as I retried the same encounter over and over and over.

I want to reiterate that I love this game, but if difficulty spikes in particular bother you, be careful going into this one.

Posso dizer que este é um jogo que valeu cada centavo gasto. 
Inicialmente imaginei que fosse só mais um Metroidvania genérico, mas o jogo tem identidade. Tem uma história bem feita, sem pontas soltas. Cada personagem é único, é possível amar alguns e odiar outros, com personalidades e visuais bem distintos um do outro.

O ponto forte deste jogo é a história. Ela passa uma mensagem interessante do que ocorre na sociedade com relação às crenças. Algumas pessoas seguem cegamente aquilo ou aqueles em quem acreditam, deixando de pensar por si próprio,  baseando-se apenas no que é dito por essas "entidades maiores". Na história é possível ver quais são as consequências dessa obediência cega. Por fim, o recado que este jogo deixa para nós é: não devemos fechar nossos olhos perante aquilo ou aqueles que seguimos. É necessário questionar, pesquisar e procurar a verdade, para que então possamos ter nossa própria opinião e não sermos manipulados. 

Indico Iconoclasts para todos que gostam de uma boa história e games 2D de plataforma ao estilo Metroidvania!

39673695.review:
NOTE: THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS!

This review is at 41% completion of the chests, and 26% completion on tweaks for anyone who is going for 100%, you could probably get another couple hours out of the game if you went for everything. I would consider it a standard run, not rushing to complete it, but not detouring for everything either. This run took just under 9 hours at the rates noted above.

Overall I'm pretty much in the meh/negative on Iconoclasts (and feeling more negative the more of this review I write). There are a variety of issues with this game and I don't think it's as simple as saying "well it was under development for 7 years". Yes that's a long time to work on a game, but I'm only going to judge it on the gameplay and the story. There are plenty of other reviews that go into graphics. It looks pretty good though there are a few places where animations seem to be missing, or where things are kind of rough.

Gameplay:

This is not a Metroidvania, there is some backtracking if you're into that for chests and such, but I don't see the point. The game is very linear and contains a good amount of puzzles, and I would consider even combat to be a sort of puzzle, so if you aren't into that stay far away, especially considering how mediocre both aspects are. There are very few upgrades/changes to how your character plays, and most of them just give you a way to solve more puzzles. You cannot gain additional health, you cannot gain additional tweak slots. [spoiler] At the end of the game you still only have the 3 tweak spots you started with, 2 wrench upgrades, and 3 weapons in total. This to me was one of the biggest disappointments of the game, my character felt the same for 75% of the game, I never felt more powerful, I never got upgrades that let me have a shorter cooldown, or that improved my stun gun in meaningful ways that made me feel like combat was faster. I just got the third upgrade and pretty much used that for the rest of the game. [/spoiler]

Due to this your character feels extremely static and there is no true feeling of improvement. I also found many of the boss fights to be annoyingly simple, but also convoluted in weird ways. There are several points in the game where it feels like you are being delayed with repetitive rooms simply to extend the play time of the game. I really disliked this and did not find the combat to be fun, it was more of a chore than anything because most of the enemies have a specific action you have to do before you can kill them so they can become vulnerable, and one later game enemy I don't even think you can kill, if so I couldn't figure it out. Either way the game is not difficult and combat is just a slog. Gunplay feels weird because it has lock on but you need to be in a specific range (all the weapons are pretty short range), grabbing things with your wrench feels bad and awkward in a variety of ways. Swinging the wrench in the "spin" maneuver which is used in combat to reflect certain projectiles is clunky, if you spin while jumping and land you come to a complete stop, there is no timer or obvious indication for the spin so you just have to learn when it ends, this isn't a huge deal, but it's annoying. [spoiler] This move is also used to charge up electricity later in the game, but requires 1 spin, and a little more for absolutely no reason other than to delay you and be annoying, I have no idea why this design decision was made but it isn't good, you'll quickly start abusing jumping and spinning to charge so you can keep moving while charging up [/spoiler]

The puzzles are okay in some spots, boring in others, and clunky in most places. I regularly felt like I wasn't doing the right thing, only to realize I was and the hitbox of an object was weird, or the method to solve something was kind of convoluted (spinning gears I'm looking at you). Often times I felt like I was somehow abusing and brute forcing the mechanics to solve the puzzles, but I couldn't figure out another way to do it and what I did worked, so what else am I supposed to think?

This leads into the next major issue for me, the way hints and direction are handled is very poor. While the game is generally very easy throughout things aren't explained very well. I still have no idea why tweaks are named differently when crafted as there seems to only actually be 5(?) different tweaks which are named the same in the menu so you have duplicates of tweaks that don't do anything else. Maybe I didn't understand something, but I saw no reason to switch my tweaks after the first hour since they're all basically the same.

The gameplay is okay, it's not as smooth as it could be, it's not as interesting as it could be, and it's not as intuitive as it could be. Overall it's only alright.

Story:

Everything below this well be spoilers, but suffice to say the story isn't good.

[spoiler] I don't even know where to start here, the story is trash, things are poorly explained and not fleshed out, and most of the characters aren't likeable. Maybe the game was going for the mysterious world, but there's not enough world building to justify that. Worse is the characters are complete garbage and most of them are not likeable in any way, nor do they undergo character transformations as the story progresses in any meaningful way. There are a few minor throaway lines and scenes at the end, but these aren't satisfying at all.

The ending is absolutely atrocious and one of the worst I've seen in years. You kill some random bad guy, why was he bad? It's not explained, what was the reason for his badness? It's not explained, where did he come from? It's not explained. The final boss DOES NOT EVEN HAVE A NAME. It's been a while since there was a game with potential for an interesting world and characters where it's cocked up so badly. There are simply too many characters that aren't fleshed out, and too many things going on that are not properly explained with a good backstory. You have a general idea of the universe, but it is in no way meaningfully fleshed out. The writing is bad and grating. I wish I had skipped all the cutscenes.


I really can't express my dissatisfaction with the overall story, and especially the ending. It seems so disconnected and clunky like it was meant for a (shitty) 100 hour teen drama RPG and stuffed into an 8 hour game.[/spoiler]


Final Verdict: Meh, skip it and get something else instead. There are other games out there that are better than Iconoclasts in every category, including price.  I can't recommend this game as I was happy to be done with it when I finally got to that point. I left it feeling frustrated and befuddled with what this game was trying to accomplish.

39672688.review:
Six years ago I played an alpha/demo for Konjak's followup to Noitu Love 2. It played well, it was unique, and even then it was gorgeous. I remember when I checked Konjak's site and the download link had changed to "Iconoclasts (cancelled)" (or something like that, it was six years ago come on). It was sad that this beautiful game would never be finished but then 8 million other indie games came out and I moved on. But I never forgot Iconoclasts. The game with the female protagonist who wasn't a destined warrior or a bounty hunter. The game where your main weapons were a stun gun and a giant wrench.

Then it actually came out, and I actually got to play it.

Iconoclasts is still a gorgeous game, it's finely detailed pixel art uses a broad colour palette and features smooth animations. There's animated cutscenes, the time investment required for that boggles my mind. The music never overtakes the scenes but is still catchy as all hell. The controls are tight, the gameplay satisfying. Bosses are challenging and unique, with multiple phases. On the harder difficulty this game will kill you. And the story, god the story. These characters are amazing.

All made by one person.

In Construct 2.

This game shouldn't exist, but it does because Konjak never gave up on it. This game is what indie games are all about.

39670472.review:
This is MY rocket.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
没错，[i]Iconoclasts[/i]开发了七年半，是一个像素画面，集解谜、动作和银河城要素于一身的着重jrpg风格的长段过场动画叙事的幻想背景游戏。在某种程度上这听起来就是Owlboy，而我很不喜欢Owlboy也并不准备讨论它。[i]Iconoclasts[/i]让我感觉2D游戏在2018年真是有一个梦寐以求的强有力开始。

就像我们说起很多其他独立Metroidvania时一样，[i]Iconoclasts[/i]同样没有什么全新的创意。这就是一个来源于经典，制作坚实的平台跳跃类游戏。主角Robin的动作灵感有不少来自于超级银河战士及以后的系列比如边缘悬挂、翻滚跳跃等等。游戏中的一些关卡也有那么一点银河战士的既视感。很多小机制的微调使游戏的解谜部分并不会像一些平台解谜类一样在操作上给人挫败感，玩家可能在堆箱子、放炸弹时感觉游戏本身在隐约的协助自己完成谜题。关卡方面，游戏中可以看到很多在其他动作游戏中被称赞的设计准则，比如隔绝新类型的敌人、无声的教学、场景叙事等等。我觉得与一些艺术主导的工作室不同，Konjak首先是个很擅长观察分析的玩家，然后也是一个出色的设计师。

[i]Iconoclasts[/i]开始的几个小时就和宣传的一样火爆且紧凑。设计巧妙爆炸不断的Boss战正是我所期待的。在一个场景中，Robin在行驶的火车上被一架长着拳头载着喋喋不休的狂热信徒的直升机追逐。玩家要做的除了躲避炮火和拳击，还需要用大号扳手去弹反扔过来的手雷，对Boss造成伤害。如果没有每次冲击的优秀音效和屏幕停滞或振动所带来的打击感以及扎实的操作手感，这个场景绝对不会有想象的那么刺激。20+Boss战的宣传可能是我见过的最不夸张的宣传，游戏中的每个Boss在气场上都足够优秀，大部分Boss都需要一定的观察和技巧的利用，同时也让人感到酣畅淋漓，毕竟有甚么比把高高在上的敌人拉下来痛砸一顿更解气的呢？

如果只是活泼的画面、跃动的音乐、爽快的Boss战和类银河战士的地图设计，[i]Iconoclasts[/i]可能就和媒体说的一样是个最合适不过的周末游戏，不错但并不杰出。宣传片中并没有展示的是游戏更深一层的本质。如果用一个词来描述[i]Iconoclasts[/i]的故事，我觉得大概是有“劲道”。确实游戏开始时像是常见的轻松动作游戏，有一些挺逗的对话，可以感觉到一个有趣的故事和广阔的世界观，但之后的发展越来越不对劲。部分场面只是有些令人不适，略显阴暗，而个别的场景可以称得上是可怖了，夹杂其中的是对人物命运的扼腕叹息。[i]Iconoclasts[/i]的故事神韵和《剑风传奇》《铳梦》这样历时数载的日本青年漫画相似，有那些残虐的场面，使得人物间的“羁绊”更为突出，但也包含了作者很个人的思考。深不深刻见仁见智，但一定是一场波折不断却又能看到星点希望的冒险。

[i]Iconoclasts[/i]的体验对一周目来说非常棒，但是重玩价值大概并不乐观。现在的情况是有的硬核玩家认为游戏过于休闲，而有些玩家和媒体则认为一些部分挫败感太强。我能说的就是[i]Iconoclasts[/i]的谜题设计大多都是看似复杂，但是解决方案非常线性，当玩家开始尝试鼓捣时，顺藤摸瓜就自然的解开了，很难被卡住。战斗方面确实有深度不足的问题。Robin的攻击方式虽然不少，但每个模块没有显著的升级，Tweak的效果也并不足够明显，对Boss没有甚么值得尝试的新玩法。我其实很期待Konjak能给我们更多的Tweak槽，但从头到尾就只有三个。End game和多周目对于普通玩家来说相对一些同类游戏并没有那么多的玩点。关于Metroidvania的争论，技术上来说[i]Iconoclasts[/i]有功能齐全的银河城连通地图，有不少的隐藏房间。但是游戏本身不停的将玩家限制在一个小地图中保证流畅的体验，所以很大一部分的探索收集要素基本上集中在最终Boss之前或通关后，拿到的奖励大部分也并不那么值得，两个隐藏Boss更注重动作性而不是解谜导致战斗方面的不足更为明显。

其他的一些值得提的点我并没有详细的说，比如[i]Iconoclasts[/i]的画面虽不像一些Hi-Bit游戏那样搞得层层叠叠的那么华丽，但动作动画真的很有风格，算是真正抓住了一些日式像素游戏的goofy fun；Konjak作为瑞典人，除了名字经常被人读错以外，他的语言习惯也和英语国家比较不同，这就导致长段的对话比较难读，尤其是几个神棍出场的时候，不过台词还是一样的漂亮；我认为[i]Iconoclasts[/i]的结局表现堪称完美，可能是我最喜欢的电子游戏结局；玩家对伙伴的对话选择看似无关紧要但其实是有影响的，算是个很有趣的小细节；[i]Iconoclasts[/i]也并不在乎甚么留白，所有我能想到的人物和地点都出现在了游戏中，或许更多，在某种程度上说没有悬念和遗憾。[i]Iconoclasts[/i]并没有创造新类型，它就是一个有紧凑的解谜和动作要素，银河城地图，线性“叙事为重”的独立游戏。作为游戏它非常扎实也足够“好玩”，但对我来说故事和人物真正让[i]Iconoclasts[/i]在同类型游戏中显得耀眼。

39666162.review:
O jogo tem um visual fantástico, um polimento fenomenal, mas simplesmente não consegue ser interessante. O review não é longo, mas se você quiser só um resumo, role até o final.

Nas primeiras horas tudo era "Uhuuuul! Olha esses efeitos! Meu deus que animações suaves, explosões, sons gostosinhos, oh yeaaah!", até que chega um momento que essas coisas deixam de ser interessantes (ou deixam de ser o seu foco) e você começa a olhar pro resto. E quando você começar a fazer isso... seu interesse pelo jogo morre. Nesse momento você enxerga defeitos como:

O combate. De início você tem uma pistola que mira automaticamente nos inimigos próximos, uma chave inglesa e um golpe de esmagada (apertando pra baixo e salto enquanto está no ar). A pistola é absurdamente fácil de usar, tudo que você precisa fazer é apertar o botão freneticamente e olhar pro inimigo. A chave inglesa não tem erro, e o esmagão é só se posicionar em cima do inimigo e executar o comando. Não achei isso um problema de início, afinal, é possível projetar inimigos que sejam divertidos e desafiadores de se enfrentar mesmo que você tenha poucos ataques e que eles sejam simples. O problema é que o jogo não faz isso. Em vez disso, coloca poucos inimigos pela fase e tudo que você precisa fazer é descobrir qual arma serve pra matar ele, e isso frequentemente não é bem comunicado. Por exemplo: se um inimigo tem espinhos no seu corpo e o único espaço aparentemente vulnerável é sua cabeça, é óbvio que o ataque que causa dano é o esmagão. Mas... e quando ele é um soldado comum? Qual ataque devo usar? Você descobre por meio de tentativa e erro, algo que não é nada divertido. E assim que você descobrir, faça o ataque repetidamente até que o inimigo esteja morto, algo que também não é divertido, mesmo com o polimento e efeitos que o jogo tem. Sem contar que tem inimigos no jogo que não são invulneráveis a ataques, qualquer ataque serve pra matá-lo. Esses são os inimigos mais ridículos, do tipo que você pode até ficar envergonhado se levar um dano dele.

Mas ok, você pode dizer que "combate não é o foco do jogo", pois de fato não é. O jogo é um puzzle platformer, que foca mais nos quebra-cabeças do que em todo resto. E como são os quebra-cabeças desse jogo? Chatos e previsíveis. Você não precisa pensar, você só precisa fazer o que claramente precisa ser feito. Por exemplo: tem um parafuso que precisa ser enroscado com sua chave inglesa, mas está alto demais pra você alcançar. Também tem algumas caixas aí perto que você pode levantar e posicionar onde quiser. O que fazer? Aposto que você, mesmo sem ter jogado o jogo, sabe como a solução é óbvia. Pegue as caixas, posicione perto do objetivo, suba nas caixas, enrosque o parafuso, e quebra-cabeça solucionado. A parte interessante de qualquer quebra-cabeça é encontrar a solução e se sentir esperto por tê-la encontrado. Como as soluções dos puzzles nesse jogo são tão óbvias, a diversão nessa parte também se perde. Não tem nenhum momento "A há!".

Os diálogos são cansativos e complicados de entender (e eu sou quase fluente em inglês). Muitas frases são esquisitas, como se fossem escritas com o propósito de parecerem mais complicadas do que são, requerindo que eu leia mais de uma vez pra compreender. Tendo que ler mais de uma vez tudo, chegou um momento em que eu não lia mais nada.

Em resumo:

Prós:
- Gráficos e animações sensacionais
- Boas músicas e efeitos sonoros
- Polimento incrível, não tem nada fora do lugar e não encontrei nenhum bug no tempo que joguei

Contras: 
- Combate fácil demais e desinteressante
- Puzzles com soluções óbvias e, consequentemente, desinteressantes
- Algumas lutas de chefe tem o ponto fraco óbvio demais e outras te deixam confuso sem saber o que fazer

Alright, I just finished and here is my take on Iconoclasts.

It’s fun, controls are good, looks nice, has some cool bosses and Black is awesome.
The music is pretty average along with it’s story, which is very drawn out and I feel doesn’t fit a game of this type; which brings me to my biggest problem with Iconoclasts (and I really hate to say this), it’s too long. 

It took me around 12 hours to finish it, and in that time I felt like I played three different games, all enjoyable but all different. The last third (and my favorite part) has a huge tonal shift from what you get at the beginning of that game, which is fine and alright in itself but there’s just so much that doesn’t need to be here, and so much that never gets a conclusion at game’s end. I’m looking at you those “new” three “agents” (you’re in the game for what? 30 minutes?) and someone’s mother…. I’ll not spoil anything else here.

Another thing that bugs me is in such a story focused game, Robin, the main character doesn’t speak, it comes off as weird when all these huge world effecting events happen and all you get is ….. On the other hand I really liked Black, her story was by far the most interesting. There’s too many places and people that are in one or two scenes and never heard from again. Characters like Grey and White add nothing but useless padding.

But enough about that. Gameplay is more important; and in that regard Iconoclasts does pretty well for itself. There’s tight controls and loads and loads of fun if a bit short bosses, quite a few puzzles, and the difficulty was just right (play it on Harder, it makes for a better experience). There’s only a hand full of upgrades in the game, but that’s ok, you get just enough to make it interesting; but I have to say the “Tweak” system was another thing that could’ve been cut. Oh, and if you’re into exploration, this isn’t going to do it for you.

I’m not going to talk about the music as I’ve already forgotten all of it, it suits it’s purpose but I can’t say I really liked a single track. Sound effects are your standard “retro” game fare and do just fine as well. 

So in the end, is the Iconoclasts worth your money? Yes, but not at full price. I can tell a lot of time and love was put into this product, but that doesn’t make it a great game. For me, it falls somewhere between Hollow Knight and Reverie Under The Moonlight and it’s miles below something like Rabi-Ribi.

At nearly 30 CAD I can’t say I’m thrilled with my experience, it honestly was fun; but it overstayed it’s welcome.

39660685.review:
Have no doubt about it, friends: Iconoclasts is a wonderful game. The core gameplay consists of roughly five mechanics, and it's executed greatly. As is true to the Metroidvania genre, you spend your time exploring a large, platforming map pulling off various feats and fights as you make your way through the story. And it's that aspect that I was wowed by!

Seriously, this game gave way more time developing its characters than I would have expected, and that's a good thing. It never felt like it went for too long in any particular scene, as the cutscenes serve as breaks usually right after something intense, such as a boss fight. (There are many good bosses.) I was legitimately fascinated by the personalities of the main reoccuring characters, and I cared for them as I discovered their flaws. I'm also extremely impressed by how the game approached their arcs, appreciating how it was chosen to address their issues in a realistic way I could sympathize with.

The gameplay itself feels silky smooth, with a flow that snaps to you after a few hours getting your boots wet. You're introduced to your gameplay mechanics one at a time, and like a great game it usually spends an area letting you test out the limits of this idea before moving on to the next. Later on, these intertwine as combinations that never felt cheap, and the smaller number of options meant it was natural to swap between them to devise an answer. The map design is also great, being large enough to feel like a fleshed out place, but never so large or needlessly structured to get lost in. Every room has its purpose, and besides a few puzzle rooms for collectables you'll encounter everything just by your own intuition. Speaking of the collectables, I'm happy to say the game never pressures you into feeling like you need to amass a large pile of things in order to have the strength to progress. It's essentially all optional, with your own loadout able to overcome the game's obstacles.

The bosses are all unique--with one maybe being more of a redux, but it's still remixed well--and there was one particular sequence that was a great emotional end to an arc that I loved. The music for that piece absolutely nailed the feeling too, wow. (Side note: great soundtrack!)

This labor of love absolutely shines, and it's a shame it feels like this game has been overshadowed by the also great Celeste. From wonderful sprite work, great music, engaging characters, to solid gameplay, this is a Metroidvania anyone with an itch should play, hands down.

39649996.review:
It's a thumbs up from me! This is a beautiful-looking, 16-bit era throwback of a game with an exceptional amount of polish that's sure to scratch the itch of many a metroidvania and/or platformer fan. It is also, 4 hours in and at 30% complete, probably not for me.

Oh, I was having a lot of fun at first! I really, really, REALLY loved how it felt like I was playing a lost SNES classic, remastered; the world is just pretty to look at, and every character is just bouncing with, well, character! The little touches like the slight auto-aim on the pistol and auto-correct on the divekick on enemies are welcome, non-intrusive bits of player aid. There are also the occasional massive, sprawling puzzle rooms, where you utilise the tools you had gathered up to that point TO THEIR MAXIMUM POTENTIAL and those can end up pretty fun; the final rewards are often a little bit meh (more components to build Tweaks that I won't use? ok) but the joy of solving said puzzle rooms are a reward in themselves.

But the further along the game I played, the more the little things just niggled at me. One example, you can use a giant wrench to leap at and hang off giant bolts in the environment, allowing you to swing off them and get to higher ground. Fine mechanic in theory, but just a little bit more fiddly than necessary; usually the bolts sit just a little bit higher than you can reach with a standing jump, so you have to do a running jump to attach the wrench to the bolt and you have to do that running jump PRECISELY otherwise you'll just sail right past it and you have to start all over again. Also, sometimes if you don't release the wrench button fast enough when you latch on the bolt, you'll automatically leap off and sometimes not in the direction you wanted to go. It's not a SUPER major issue, and I succeed at it like... 75% of the time; but it's just a little bit of niggling annoyance that happens over and over again (amongst various other little things) in the game that added up and ruined the "flow" of the game for me.

And at the centre of things that annoy me in this game are the boss battles. Normally, I'm all for boss battles that rely on puzzle-like mechanics to defeat as opposed to being a bulletsink with a zillion hitpoints; but the lack of signposting of what you're supposed to do with some of these bosses is aggravating as all get out. Like yeah, I get that I'm supposed to use a particular attack at a certain point in the boss' attack cycle, but which attack (charged or not) and which cycle and do I actually have all that guesswork right only I'm not standing on the EXACT spot that I needed to be etc etc etc. I actually started to yearn for bulletsink bosses after a certain point, because at least for those guys you can still do chip damage and feel like you're actually progressing (however slowly).

And lastly, while I think the story is surprisingly meaty and filled with pretty cool characters and funny moments, I also feel the script needed a second pass by a native English speaker? It was pretty okay at the beginning, but as the game progressed it felt like I was reading the English subtitles from a knockoff Hong Kong DVD; filled with "DO NOT WANT"isms and "I got knife scars more than the number of your leg's hair"alings. This can actually be a source of fun after a certain point though, so your mileage may vary!

All that said, I easily recommend the game based on the visuals and the obvious love and care lavished on the game; and honestly, a lot of the things I was personally bothered by may not be a problem for anybody else! As for me, I may wait until a full guide to taking the bosses comes out, because I'd rather not waste time figuring out the one attack that will damage the boss at the exact moment because it is completely invincible otherwise.

39648065.review:
The 2012 alpha demo of Iconoclasts has been sitting on my computer for years. I've always kept coming back to it, sometimes not even just to play it, but to closely analyze its design. It's been a strong and direct inspiration for my own game development, as have been some of the creator's tweets, so needless to say, this has been one of my all-time most anticipated games.

Absolutely worth the wait. The game starts good, then it steadily works its way uphill to a legendary place.

While it's been classified on Steam as a Metroidvania, Iconoclasts has relatively little exploration or backtracking compared to most games in the genre. It's a largely linear, densely-packed platformer that moves along at a smooth pace, for the most part. The tools you acquire throughout the journey quickly become second nature thanks to the intuitive controls, and they're constantly utilized to solve satisfying, often action-oriented puzzles.

Boss fights are a major gameplay focus. All of them are good, most of them are great, and a few are unadulterated awesomeness. However, there are occasions when a lot of experimentation is required to discern how to deal damage to a boss, disrupting the pacing somewhat.

The narrative is the real driving forces of the experience. I'd say it's impressive and unpredictable enough to bring video games an important step closer to being a more widely-appreciated storytelling medium. Clearly the product of years of ideas, it is refreshingly complex, if a bit ovewhelming. I have no problem with a game having a well-developed world, or a story that takes more than one playthrough to fully appreciate. But I do wish a bit more time was spent familiarizing the player with the world's unfamiliar infrastructure from the beginning; I felt as though my emotional investment in the characters was delayed because I didn't understand their roles yet. A few lines of dialogue also read like forced exposition, which momentarily breaks the immersion from the generally great characters.

I have three complaints with 100% completion. First, there are no descriptions for the key items in the pause screen, meaning you can carry around an optional letter with no hints or reminders on who the intended recipient is. Second, there doesn't appear to be a more efficient way to check the treasure-collecting percentages of each area, short of revisiting each one and checking the map. A visible list of the areas and their percent of completion would be convenient. Third, the means by which you reach hidden items are occasionally horrendously unclear, not even offering a semblance of a hint. It's a shame that most of the optional aspects of the game feel like an afterthought, design-wise, since the main game is so strong.

Iconoclasts is a very human game, and a delightfully ambitious one that's always on the move and changing things up. A captivating, entertaining creation that I know will continue to inspire me.

Es geht um eine Frau, deren Papa scheinbar tot ist und seinen Schraubschlüssel ihr vermacht hat. Das Haus der Nachbarin wurde von einem Roboter zerstört. Agenten des höheren Galubensbekenntnisses sind männliche Frauen, die Schwarz und Weiss heissen und der Protagonistin verbieten, Häuser zu flicken. Sie geht los ins Dorf. Dort sind die Leute sauer auf sie, weil sie Häuser flickt, worauf der Mond bröckelt und die Sünde Häuser bombardiert. Andere NPSs sind entweder Hausfrauen oder Piratinnen. Alle beten zu einer Mutter, welche zu einem "Er" reden kann. Der Bruder hat Streit mit seiner Familie. In der Kirche gibt mir jemand eine Batterie. Die Agenten erwischen uns und machen das Haus des Bruders kaputt und fühlen sich erhaben, indem sie allen ihren Glauben aufzwingen wollen. Wir werden mit einer Piratin eingesperrt, welche einen Baum in eine Türe pflanzt, worauf wir durch den Estrich einer Bar kriechen. Dann bombt uns ein Soldat ins Wasser, wir werden rausgefischt und gleich wieder reingeworfen. Dann landen wir in der Wüste. Später helfen wir den Soldaten, einen Fahrstuhl zu bedienen. Dann kommt ein Prinz, der Blumen aus dem Boden zaubert und wir verlieben uns. Dann tritt ein dürrer Mann einen anderen von der Klippe während er missionarisch aus einem Buch zitiert und einheitliche Meinung propagiert und gleichzeitig eine pummelige Soldatin als Lover hat. Die Schwarze Agentin ist am trauern. Dann entgleist der Prinz einen Zug mit Zauberkraft und wir landen bei den Piraten. Und das innerhalb 2.5 Stunden Spiel. Alles klar?

- Die Figuren:
Frauen. Das ist das Wort, welches es zusammenfasst, ohne es zu werten. Es sind irgendwie alles Frauen, selbst die Männer. Und obschon das Spiel vermutlich explizit so aufgemacht ist, um Frauen-Power hervorzuheben, komme ich nicht herum, zu denken, dass der Schuss ziemlich nach hinten los ist. Es ist klischiiert und teils sexistisch. Nicht, dass es nicht andere Spiele gäbe, wo dies noch viel krasser ist, aber gerade bei diesem Spiel stört es gewaltig, weil es vermutlich genau das Gegenteil hätte sein sollen.

- Boss-Battles:
Dauern nicht länger wie 2-3 Minuten, braucht vielleicht 2 Versuche, da man nicht sieht, was man tun muss. Sehr einfach. Das grösste Problem ist, dass der Bildschirm sehr stark wackelt und immer wieder Sprechblasen auftauchen, die man versucht ist, zu lesen, was aber meist nur stört.

- Plattforming und Rätsel:
Nach 2.5 Stunden im Spiel dauerte das komplexeste Rätsel vielleicht 5 Minuten, weil es sich über 4 Bildschirme erstreckte. Plattforming ist easy und zugegebenermassen flüssig und schnell, aber die Steuerung spielt manchmal einen Streich.

- Mission - Motivation:
Wieso tue ich, was ich tue, was tue ich, warum, wohin muss ich, wer hilft mir... Keine Ahnung. Es gibt bereits in den 2.5 gespielten Stunden mehrere Situationen, bei welchen ich mich fragte: Und was tue ich jetzt? Ich irrte beispielsweise 15 Minuten erfolglos rum, um den Prinzen in sein "Camp" zu bringen. Ich musste schlussenlich online nachschauen gehen.

- Cutscenes:
Von den 2.5 Stunden waren gefühlt 1.5 Cutscenes. Manche Cutscenes scheinen bislang völlig unnütz zu sein (Beispielsweise die Szene mit dem Schiff). Ich vermute, die Intention der Spielemacher war, die männlichen Figuren in den Cutscenes als bösartig und unmenschlich darzustellen, oft ist es aber einfach nur langweilig. Die längste dauerte rund 20 Minuten, unterbrochen mit einem viel zu einfachen Boss-Fight.

- Steuerung:
Grundsätzlich nicht schlecht, reagiert sehr schnell. Aber Kombinationen von Tasten klemmen, weswegen man häufig in die falsche Richtung blickt, sich nicht sauber an den Wänden festhält und runterfällt und manchmal die Tools einfach nicht funktionieren. Aktionsmuster werden nicht genügend geübt, weswegen die Tasten und deren Kombinationen sehr schnell wieder verlernt werden, was zu ständigen Fehlern führt. Sowieso sind vier Aktionstasten zuviel für die Spielemechanik, siehe nächster Punkt.

- Das Tool: Das Ikonische an dem Spiel ist der riesige Schraubenschlüssel. Aber ehrlich gesagt könnte man die Spielemechanik locker ohne bewerkstelligen. Es würde reichen, Buttons zu drücken, anstelle sie mit dem Schlüssel drehen zu müssen. Es würde reichen, sich an Haken festzuhalten, anstelle sich mit dem Schlüssel daran festzuhalten. Und es würde ohne Probleme funktionieren, einfach zu parieren, anstelle mit dem Schlüssel zu schlagen, bzw die paar wenigen Gegner, bei welchen dies tatsächlich einen Effekt hat, einfach weglassen oder umprogrammieren. Sprich: Das Spiel käme auch ohne aus.

Fazit:
Zu einfach, zu konfus.

39636309.review:
The art is fantastic, the bosses are fun, and the movement feels very fluid. 

It's a solid metroidvania all around, but it's not a traditional metroidvania in the slightest. While most metroidvania games tend to take from the big titles like Super Metroid and Castlevania Symphony of the Night, Konjak seems to draw more of his inspiration from Metroid Fusion and Castlevania Order of Ecclesia. This shows in the fact that upgrades are extremely sparse due to the game's preference to give you everything you need and let you work with the existing mechanics instead, as well as the fact that this game is very boss heavy and those bosses are all very fun to fight. 

The music is probably the game's weakest component. It's not bad. It is simply serviceable. It does the job, but it doesn't do it at peak performance. You may find most of the tracks to be forgettable in the long run, but it's clear that this is not where Konjak truly shines, and that's fine. 

This game is also a very narrative and dialogue heavy metroidvania, so that may put off people expecting the traditional metroidvania fare of being given a sparse narrative and letting you explore the world to figure things out. The story is told quite deliberately through character interaction and dialogue rather than personal, environmental interaction as one would usually expect from this type of game. The stark contrast of fast-paced gameplay into slower paced narrative bits may not gel well with a lot of people, but if you're actually into that, then you'll have no problems here.

The narrative and themes themselves may seem heavyhanded, but as the name of the game suggests, that's pretty much to be expected. The dialogue can feel a bit preachy at times and there are points in the story that don't feel as well written as they could have been, but it does a decent enough job at establishing the circumstances of the world. It may feel like all doom and gloom at first, but there's plenty of comedy to break of the drama. 

Iconoclasts also features a challenge mode after you beat the game once which adds new attacks to bosses and has the player dying in one hit.

TL;DR: Game is fun, music is serviceable, art is amazing, and it's a very story heavy metroidvania which may not be for everyone.
